title: In the Matter of C. Craig Young
description: The Court found misconduct and imposed a Public Reprimand on an attorney.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of C. Craig Young, Respondent.
      
    
  


Public Reprimand

Opinion No. 26241
Heard June 20, 2006 - Filed January 3, 2007Â Â  


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster and Senior Assistant Attorney General James Bogle, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Reynolds Williams, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The Full Panel (Panel) adopted the report of the Hearing Master finding Respondentâ€™s misconduct in litigation was more â€œunprofessionalâ€ than â€œunethical,â€ and recommending that the Court discipline Respondent by issuing an admonition.Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) appeals, contending the Panel erred in failing to find Respondent violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR (RPC), to recommend a more severe sanction, and to require Respondent to pay $1,552.00 as the costs of the proceeding.Â  We agree with ODC that Respondent violated the RPC, that a public reprimand is the appropriate sanction, and that Respondent should pay costs.
FACTS
Respondent undertook the representation of an attorney (Ruffin) in litigation arising out of Ruffinâ€™s participation in a limited liability company (LLC).Â  Ruffin and two doctors formed the LLC to purchase property and build an office building.Â  Ruffin would be responsible for overseeing the construction and associated issues, and would be a tenant in the building, while the doctors would provide the financial backing.
In 1998, the LLC members began to feel uneasy about the business, and in 1999 the doctors commenced civil litigation on their individual behalves and on behalf of the LLC against Ruffin individually and against Ruffinâ€™s legal practice.Â  The plaintiffs were represented by Jerome P. Askins, III, and the defendants by Respondent.Â  Askins is a personal friend of the doctors, while Respondent was a friend of Ruffin.Â  The Panel found, and the record supports the finding, that personal friendship adversely affected Respondentâ€™s professional judgment in this matter.
In July 1999, Respondent and Askins appeared before a circuit judge and the outline of a settlement agreement was placed on the record.Â  The agreement had been roughed-out between Respondent and Askins at the courthouse that day.Â  When Ruffin could not obtain financing in time to close the deal as agreed at the July hearing, the parties agreed to an extension.Â  Relationships between the parties and between the attorneys became increasingly acrimonious as it was learned that Ruffin had, in fact, misused LLC funds,[1] and as the settlement was postponed.Â  The closing was reset for October 6, 1999.
On October 5 and 6, the parties executed a Revised Purchase Agreement.Â  On October 6, Respondent faxed to Askins a document, labeled â€œDraft,â€ entitled â€œSEVERANCE AGREEMENT, RELEASE AND HOLD HARMLESS, AND CONFIDENTIALITY AGREEMENTâ€ (Severance Agreement).Â  Two paragraphs of this Severance Agreement are at issue in the present disciplinary action:

  5.Â  In exchange for receiving the consideration set forth herein, [the Doctors] hereby agree and acknowledge that neither they nor [the] LLC have been a legal client of Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr. and/or Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr., P.C.
  6.Â  [The Doctors] agree to keep this Agreement, the reasons for withdrawing from the LLC, and all matters pertaining to the lawsuit captioned [Doctors] Individually and for the Benefit of [the] LLC, a South Carolina Limited Liability Company v. Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr. and Thomas E. Ruffin, Jr., P.C. completely confidential.Â  In the event that the existence of this Agreement or facts pertaining to the limited liability company and/or the above-referenced lawsuit become known and it can be proved by Mr. Ruffin that such knowledge has come about as a result of [the Doctors] breaching the Confidentiality Agreement, then [one Doctor] and/or [the other Doctor], their heirs and/or assigns shall repay the One Hundred Forty Eight Thousand and 00/100 ($148,000.00) Dollars set forth in this Agreement upon demand, plus interest at the rate of one and one half percent (1 Â½%) per month.

We refer to Paragraph 5 as the â€œLegal Representation Clauseâ€ and Paragraph 6 as the â€œConfidentiality Clause.â€
These two paragraphs caused the entire settlement to fail.Â  The doctors were unwilling to agree to the false[2] Legal Representation Clause, and unwilling to agree to the one-sided Confidentiality Clause.Â  Part of the problem arose because these two paragraphs were â€œin additionâ€ to the terms placed on the record before the circuit judge, and were not presented to the doctors until mere hours before the settlement agreement was to be consummated.[3]
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  After reviewing the Severance Agreement and speaking with the doctors, Askins called Respondent.Â  The Panel found that the â€œtelephone conversation became heated on both sides, and when Askins threatened to â€˜take Ruffin to the Barâ€™ if Ruffin did not â€˜cooperateâ€™ in the settlement, Respondent said: â€˜I am not going to let [Ruffin] buy the building [from the LLC] and have the Doctors run to the Bar and yank his license.â€[4]Â  Askins then faxed a letter to Respondent suggesting alterations to the Severance Agreement, including the deletion of both the Legal Representation Clause and the Confidentiality Clause.Â  Respondent replied by sending an intemperate letter to Askins, stating among other things, that â€œas a result of your bad faith, the transaction and settlement cannot take place.â€Â  Respondent subsequently sent Askins another letter, â€œclarifyingâ€ his earlier letter and â€œconfirmingâ€ that, prior to sending the first letter, Respondent had offered to redraft the Legal Representation Clause to reflect that Ruffinâ€™s firm had, in fact, represented the LLC in some mechanicâ€™s lien matters, and offering to reword the Confidentiality Clause. 
The events of October 6 led to a complete breakdown in relations between the parties and their attorneys.Â  On October 15, 1999, Askins was served with Ruffinâ€™s Answer, Counterclaim, and Third-Party Complaint.Â  The Third-Party Complaint drafted by Respondent alleged Askins and the doctors had violated the civil RICO Act[5] and had committed the tort of outrage against Ruffin.Â  Upon receipt of these pleadings, Askins withdrew from representation of the doctors and the LLC.Â  Respondent withdrew soon after.Â  The underlying suit was eventually settled by Ruffinâ€™s payment of sums to both Askins and the doctors, and the LLC.
PANEL FINDINGS
The Panel found that Respondent was â€œaggressiveâ€ in propounding the Severance Agreement and in deciding to file the Third Party Complaint (RICO action).Â  The Panel recommended Respondent be admonished â€œagainst emotional reactions and attachments in the practice of law, which can not only cloud judgment, recollection, and analysis, but also lead to intemperate conduct towards fellow members of the bar.â€Â  
A.Â  Severance Agreement
The Panel concluded that by the time the October 1999 documents were prepared, the settlement agreement put before the circuit court in July 1999 â€œhad simplyâ€¦come off the railsâ€¦.â€Â  The Panel found Respondent believed the relationship between Ruffin and the doctors related solely to a business deal, and did not implicate the practice of law, but â€œwas aggressively one-sided in his attempt to lay that factual issue to rest.â€[6]Â  It found Respondentâ€™s aggressiveness in proposing the Severance Agreement was mitigated by the fact it was merely a draft, which Respondent quickly offered to correct when the â€œLegal Representationâ€ error was pointed out.Â  Finally, the Panel found â€œRespondentâ€™s judgment and memory were likely affected by the friendship with his client, and Respondent was erecting positive barriers to potential disciplinary action.Â  Respondent should be admonished that his conduct here was unprofessional.â€
We defer to the Panelâ€™s findings and conclusions regarding the Severance Agreement.
While the â€œLegal Representation Clauseâ€ was patently false, we defer to the Panelâ€™s finding, premised on its belief in Respondentâ€™s credibility, that the factual error in this clause was the result of an honest oversight by Respondent, which he immediately offered to correct when it was called to his attention.Â  As to the â€œConfidentiality Clause,â€ the Panel found it was merely a draft, created in the course of emotional litigation, which was the result of Respondentâ€™s overly-aggressive representation of Ruffin.Â  We accept the Panelâ€™s findings here, but not without noting that based upon Respondentâ€™s conduct and statements at oral argument before the Court, we have grave reservations whether Respondentâ€™s aggressiveness in the Ruffin litigation was an isolated event, or whether Respondent approaches the practice of law in general from a gladiatorial perspective.Â  Respondent would be well-served to reflect upon his attitude and demeanor.
B.Â  RICO Claim
ODC contends Respondent violated the RPC in filing the RICO claim.Â  We agree.
The RICO complaint alleges that the doctors and Askins engaged in an enterprise using â€œthe U.S. mails and the telephone systems to convey threats and other extortionate communications.â€Â  These defendants were alleged to have violated state and federal laws, specifically two state statutes proscribing unlawful use of a telephone,[7] and blackmail,[8] and federal racketeering statutes.[9]Â  The RICO complaint also alleged that the three defendants unlawfully conspired to violate these state criminal statutes and/or were accessories to their violation.
At the disciplinary hearing, Respondent testified that to the factual basis for the RICO claim:

  1)     Ruffin told him one of the doctors had, in a July 1999 telephone conversation, stated that if Ruffin did not settle the case in the manner the doctors felt like it needed to be, then they would go to S.L.E.D. or the sheriff;
  2)     Askins told Respondent in a telephone conversation that he wanted to â€œstomp [Ruffinâ€™s] ass;â€
  3)     Askins told Respondent in a phone call that if the case were not settled on the doctorsâ€™ terms then the doctors would go to S.L.E.D., the solicitorâ€™s office, the attorney generalâ€™s office, the sheriff or disciplinary counsel; and
  4)     The CPA involved in the case told Respondent that in a phone conversation Askins had told the CPA that if Ruffin did not settle on the doctorsâ€™ terms, â€œthen there would be disciplinary action involved.â€Â  

Respondent testified he viewed the enterpriseâ€™s common purpose to be to extort as much money as possible from Ruffin in settling the civil litigation and winding up the partiesâ€™ business relationship. 
Respondent also testified that while he did not dispute the right of any of the RICO defendants to report a crime, the threats in this case violated the blackmail statute because they were made with the intent to extort money from Ruffin.[10]Â  When asked what evidence he had to support the claim that the defendants had violated the unlawful use of a telephone statute, which prohibits among other things profane, vulgar, indecent or immoral words over the phone, Respondent referred to Askinsâ€™ threat to stomp Ruffinâ€™s ass, and to the extortionate threats as â€œimmoral.â€Â  We note that in Respondentâ€™s factual recitation, only one of the doctors is alleged to have made threats although both were sued.
The RICO complaint drafted by Respondent alleged a violation of 18 U.S.C. Â§ 1957, which concerns engaging in monetary transactions in property derived from specific unlawful activities.Â  When asked to explain the factual basis for this allegation, Respondent was unable to provide one, and testified he would have to do some research in order to answer.Â  When he was then asked whether he had done any research prior to filing this RICO claim, Respondent replied he had not, but had instead relied upon knowledge gained in connection with other RICO claims he had handled. 
Rule 3.1, RPC, provides that â€œA lawyer shall not bringâ€¦a proceedingâ€¦unless there is a basis in law and fact for doing so that is not frivolousâ€¦.â€Â  The comments to this rule state, in part, that lawyers are required â€œto inform themselves about the facts of their clientsâ€™ cases and the applicable law and determine that they can make good faith arguments in support of their clientsâ€™ positions.â€Â  It is apparent from Respondentâ€™s testimony that he did no investigation into either the state criminal law upon which his RICO complaint is predicated, nor did he conduct any research into the federal RICO law as it may apply to these facts before proceeding to make these grave allegations against Askins and the doctors.Â  Respondent testified he checked with two (unnamed) members of his firm before filing the RICO complaint, at least one of whom urged him not to file.Â  Respondent presents himself as a RICO expert, and accordingly cannot rely upon his consultations with others to insulate him from a finding that he brought a frivolous RICO claim.Â  Compare In re Ruffin, supra.
The Panel found, based implicitly on a determination that Respondent was the most credible witness, that Askins and at least one of the doctors had made the statements against Ruffin that Respondent alleged they had made.Â  However, whether these â€œthreatsâ€ were violative of the state criminal blackmail statute or the unlawful use of a telephone statute is highly doubtful.Â  What is clear is that Respondent had no facts implicating one of the doctors he sued, nor did he conduct any legal research before filing this complaint.Â  Further, Respondent was unable to explain the legal basis for at least part of his pleading at this disciplinary hearing, and never contemplated whether South Carolina would recognize a blackmail violation where the defendant threatened to report the plaintiffâ€™s criminal activity to law enforcement and/or disciplinary authorities.
We find clear and convincing evidence that Respondent violated the following ethical rules in filing this retaliatory RICO complaint against the doctors and Attorney Askins: Rule 3.1 (lawyer shall not bring a frivolous proceeding); and Rule 1.1(5) (competent representation includes thoroughness and preparation).
CONCLUSION
This Court may make its own findings of fact and conclusions of law regarding allegations of misconduct.Â  In re Ruffin, supra.Â  Based upon our review of the entire record in this matter, we find Respondent committed ethical misconduct in the RICO complaint matter.Â  Further, we disagree with the Panelâ€™s recommendation that Respondent receive only an admonition for his misconduct in the Ruffin litigation, and instead impose a Public Reprimand.[11]Â  Finally, we order that Respondent pay, within fifteen (15) days of the date of the filing of this opinion, $1,552.00 for costs.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justice Edward B. Cottingham, concur.

[1] Ruffin was indefinitely suspended for this misconduct.Â  In re Ruffin, 363 S.C. 347, 610 S.E.2d 803 (2005).
[2] As will be explained infra, Ruffinâ€™s firm had in fact represented the LLC in several mechanicâ€™s liens actions.
[3] The terms agreed to at the hearing pertained primarily to the division of the LLCâ€™s assets, while the Severance Agreement was intended to establish the terms of the dissolution of the business relationship.
[4] In making the finding that these two statements were made, the Hearing Master necessarily resolved credibility questions in favor of Respondent.Â  While we are not bound by the Panelâ€™s findings, we give great weight to those findings which are premised on witness credibility.Â  E.g., In re Flom, 356 S.C. 246, 588 S.E.2d 593 (2003).
[5] RICO is an acronym for the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act.Â  See 18 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1961 et seq.
[6] We accept the Panelâ€™s conclusion that in drafting the Severance Agreement Respondent was influenced by his firmly held belief that the doctors and Ruffin had only a business relationship governed by applicable fiduciary duties and not a legal relationship in a general sense.Â  See also In re Ruffin, supra, holding there was no â€œgeneral legal relationship.â€
[7] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-430.
[8] Â§ 16-11-640.
[9] 18 U.S.C.Â§Â§ 1951; 1952; and 1957.
[10] While â€˜truthâ€™ is generally not a defense to blackmail charges based upon extortionate threats to expose non-criminal behavior, it is unclear whether the â€˜truthâ€™ of a threat to refer someone for criminal charges, i.e. that the person actually committed the offense, is a defense to extortion.Â  See Annot., Truth as a defense to state charges of criminal intimidation, extortion, blackmail, threats and the like, based upon threats to disclose information about the victim, 39 A.L.R. 4th 1011 (1985).Â  We need not decide the novel issue today, but point out that Respondent never even considered whether threats to report a crime could be the basis of a criminal prosecution under the blackmail statute.
[11] In 2005 we accepted an Agreement for Discipline by Consent in an unrelated disciplinary matter involving Respondent and imposed a public reprimand where Respondent admitted sending a settlement proposal which threatened criminal prosecution to gain an advantage in a civil matter, and which mischaracterized part of the proposed settlement as a gift.Â  In re Young, 366 S.C. 180, 621 S.E.2d 359 (2005).

title: Sloan v. Hardee
description: The issue in this case is whether certain DOT Commissioners are serving in violation of SC Code Ann. Â§Â§ 57-1-320(B) and 57-1-330(A).
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Edward D. Sloan, Jr., individually, and on behalf of all others similarly situated, and the South Carolina Public Interest Foundation, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        John N. Hardee, Robert W. Harrell, John Moultrie "Moot" Truluck, Respondents.
      
    
  


IN THE ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No. 26242
Heard November 2, 2006 - Filed January 8, 2007Â Â  


  
    
      
        James G. Carpenter, of Greenville, for Petitioner.
        A. Camden Lewis, Keith M. Babcock, Ariail E. King, and Linda C. McDonald, all of Columbia, E. LeRoy Nettles, Sr., and Marian D. Nettles, of Lake City, Gedney M. Howe, III, of Charleston, Keith D. Munson, of Greenville, and S. Jahue Moore, of W. Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We accepted this matter in our original jurisdiction to address whether Respondents, Commissioners for the South Carolina Department of Transportation (DOT), were appointed in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-1-330(A)(2006).Â  
FACTS
Hardee, Harrell and Truluck are DOT Commissioners.Â  Hardee was appointed to a four-year term, to be served from February 18, 1998 to February 15, 2002.Â Â  In June 2001, his legislative delegation re-elected him to serve a second term, from February 2002 until August 2002.Â Â  Thereafter, in May 2002, his legislative delegation re-elected him to serve as DOT Commissioner from August 15, 2002 to August 15, 2006.Â  In January 2005, Hardee was re-elected to serve from August 2006 until August 2010.
Harrell was elected in May 1999 to serve as DOT Commissioner from February 2000 until February 15, 2004.Â  He has been re-elected to serve from February 15, 2004 through February 15, 2008. 
Truluck was elected to serve his first term as DOT Commissioner from February 15, 1998 until February 15, 2002.Â  He served in a hold-over capacity until May 15, 2002, at which time he was re-elected to serve from May 15, 2002 through May 15, 2006.Â  
Petitioners, Sloan and the South Carolina Public Interest Foundation, instituted this complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief, contending the Commissioners were serving in violation of SC Code Ann. Â§Â§ 57-1-320(B) and 57-1-330(A).Â  We accepted the matter in our original jurisdiction.[1]
DISCUSSION
Title 57 of the South Carolina Code establishes the DOT and sets up transportation districts in accord with state congressional districts.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-1-310 (2006) requires the DOT Commission to be composed of one member from each transportation district elected by the delegations of each congressional district, and one at-large member appointed by the Governor.Â  This section further requires that â€œ[s]uch elections or appointment, as the case may be, shall take into account race and gender so as to represent, to the greatest extent possible, all segments of the population of the State.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-1-320 (2006), entitled, â€œCounty divided among two or more districts; consecutive terms limited; limit on commissioners from same county,â€ states, in pertinent part:

  (B) No county within a Department of Transportation district shall have a resident commission member for more than one consecutive term and in no event shall any two persons from the same county serve as a commission member simultaneously except as provided hereinafter.Â Â  

(Emphasis supplied).Â  Section 57-1-330 provides: 

  All commission members must serve for a term of office of four years which expires on February fifteenth of the appropriate year.Â  Commissioners shall continue to serve until their successors are elected and qualify, provided that a commissioner may only serve in a hold over capacity for a period not to exceed six months. . . . No person is eligible to serve as a commission member who is not a resident of that district at the time of his appointment, except that the at large commission member may be appointed from any county in the State regardless of whether another commissioner is serving from that county.

Sloan and the SC Public Interest Foundation contend Hardee, Harrell, and Truluck are serving in violation of the above provisions, as they are currently serving in a second or subsequent â€œconsecutive term.â€Â Â  We agree.Â Â Â  
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to ascertain and effectuate the intention of the legislature.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  When a statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its literal meaning. Â Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314 S.C. 137, 139, 442 S.E.2d 177, 179 (1994).Â  Words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Bryant v. City of Charleston, 295 S.C. 408, 368 S.E.2d 899 (1988); State v. Blackmon, 304 S.C. 270, 273, 403 S.E.2d 660, 662 (1991).Â  
â€œConsecutiveâ€ is defined as â€œsuccessive; succeeding one another in regular order; to follow in uninterrupted succession.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, 276 (5th Ed. 1979).Â  The plain and unambiguous meaning of the phrase â€œmore than one consecutive termâ€ is that a DOT commissioner may serve one term and may not serve a succeeding, consecutive term.
Respondents contend the term â€œconsecutive,â€ permits a commissioner to serve one term, consecutive to a first term such that the commissioners may actually serve two successive terms.Â  We disagree.Â  Such a construction would produce an absurd result, clearly not intended by the Legislature.Â  
There are numerous statutes which permit certain commissioners or board members to serve â€œtwo consecutive terms.â€Â  See e.g. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-13-40 (Human Affairs Commissioner having served two consecutive terms shall be eligible for reappointment one year after the expiration of his second term); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-15-10 (Commission on Women members ineligible to serve more than two consecutive terms); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-61-20 (State Board of Examiners for Registered Environmental Sanitarian members are eligible for reappointment but cannot serve more than two consecutive terms); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-180 (State Health Planning Committee members are appointed for four-year terms, and may serve only two consecutive terms); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 55-11-320 (Richland/Lexington Airport Commission members may not serve more than two consecutive terms).Â  To construe the phrase â€œconsecutiveâ€ as meaning a term, consecutive to a first term, would result in the phrase â€œtwo consecutive termsâ€, in actuality, meaning two terms consecutive to a first, for a total of three terms.[2]Â  To construe the statutes as asserted by Appellants would produce an absurd result.Â  Charleston Trident Home Builders Inc. v. Town Council of Summerville, 369 S.C. 498, 632 S.E.2d 864 (2006); Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994) (when construing a statute, the Court will reject meaning that would lead to an absurd result not intended by the legislature).
Lastly, Respondent Hardee contends South Carolina Public Interest Foundation v. Judicial Merit Selection Commâ€™n, 369 S.C. 139, 632 S.E.2d 277 (2006), requires we refrain from ruling on this matter because it presents questions which are exclusively or predominantly political in nature rather than judicial.Â  We disagree.Â Â  In the Public Interest Foundation case, we held that whether the Judicial Merit Selection Commission properly evaluated a candidate seeking election to a circuit court seat was a nonjusticiable political question because the power to determine if a person is qualified to hold judicial office is vested with the General Assembly by the State Constitution.Â  The issue raised there was that the Commission did not adequately investigate whether a candidate met residency requirements for the Fourteenth Judicial Circuit. 
Public Interest Foundation has no application here.Â Â  The sole issue in this case is whether the Commissioners are serving in violation of the statutory terms.Â Â  Defining the meaning of the phrase â€œmore than one consecutive termâ€ is clearly within the prerogative of this Court.Â  Cf. Lindsay v. Natâ€™l Old Line Ins. Co., 262 S.C. 621, 629, 207 S.E.2d 75, 78 (1974) (judicial interpretation of a statute is determinative of its meaning and effect).
Accordingly, we hold section 57-1-320(B) prohibits a DOT Commissioner from serving a consecutive term of office.Â  
MOORE, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justices Deadra L. Jefferson and G. Thomas Cooper, concur.

[1]Â  We find this matter of sufficient public interest as to confer standing on Petitioners.Â  Sloan v. Wilkins, 362 S.C. 430, 608 S.E.2d 579 (2005); Baird v. Charleston Cty., 333 S.C. 519, 531, 511 S.E.2d 69, 75 (1999) (standing is not inflexible and standing may be conferred upon a party when an issue is of such public importance as to require its resolution for future guidance). 
[2]Â  Analogously, Article IV, Â§ 3 of the South Carolina Constitution provides that â€œno person shall be elected Governor for more than two successive terms.â€Â  Carried to its logical conclusion, â€œsuccessiveâ€ as interpreted by the Commissioners would permit the Governor to serve for a total of three successive terms.Â

title: State v. Burkhart
description: In this death penalty case, the Court finds inadmissible evidence in the sentencing phase regarding general prison conditions.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Troy Alan Burkhart, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Anderson County
J.C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26243
Heard September 20, 2006 - Filed January 8, 2007Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; REMANDED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina Theos Adams, of Anderson, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant shot and killed three people in a rural area of Anderson County on November 19, 1997.Â  The victims were brothers Shane and Stacy Walters, aged twenty-seven and twenty-two, and Sonya Cann, aged twenty-one.Â  Appellant was convicted of three counts of murder and three counts of possessing a firearm during the commission of a violent crime and sentenced to death.Â  These convictions were overturned on appeal.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298 (2002).Â  In March 2004, appellant was again convicted and sentenced to death.Â  We affirm appellantâ€™s convictions but reverse and remand for resentencing.
FACTS
Appellant became acquainted with brothers Shane and Stacy Walters on a Friday night when they met at a mutual friendâ€™s home.Â  Appellant asked the brothers for help with the septic tank at his restaurant.Â  They worked together and socialized over the course of the weekend.Â  All three used methamphetamine repeatedly from Friday until late into the night on Sunday.Â  At about 5:00 a.m. Monday morning, the three men went to pick up Shaneâ€™s girlfriend, Sonya, at her home.Â  The four of them drove off in Shaneâ€™s extended-cab â€œduallyâ€ truck.Â  The victims were not seen alive again.
Later that morning, at about 8:15 a.m., appellant came to the Seneca police department and told police he had killed three people in self-defense.Â  He led police to a secluded kudzu field where police found the bodies of Shane, Stacy, and Sonya on the ground.Â  The truck was recovered from where appellant had parked it at his fatherâ€™s house.Â  Its interior was covered with blood.Â  Forensic evidence indicated that all three victims had been shot in the head at close range while seated in the cab of the truck and their bodies had been dragged onto the ground.Â  The State also produced evidence that Stacy and Shane had been stomped while on the ground and Sonya was shot in the head while lying there. 
The only weapon used was appellantâ€™s semi-automatic pistol which could hold eight rounds, seven in the magazine and one in the chamber.[1]Â  Two empty magazines were at the scene indicating appellant had reloaded.Â  Experts estimated up to eleven shots could have been fired.Â  
ISSUES

  1.     Was the exclusion of evidence in the guilt phase prejudicial?
  2.     Was the admission of evidence regarding prison conditions in the sentencing phase reversible error?

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Exclusion of evidence in guilt phase
Appellant claimed self-defense.Â  He testified that he killed the victims because he believed the brothers had been hired to kill him by his uncle, Ronnie Burkhart, an infamous drug-dealer with whom appellant was on bad terms.Â  
Appellant testified that when they arrived at the kudzu field, Shane was holding appellantâ€™s gun because appellant had given it to him to shoot at a deer earlier.Â  While they were sitting in the truck, Shane asked appellant if he had ever wronged â€œUncle Ronnie.â€Â  Because appellant had been threatened by Ronnie and was surprised that Shane knew Ronnie, he immediately became anxious.Â  Shane then pointed the gun at appellant and ordered him out of the truck.Â  Stacy said, â€œWeâ€™re going to make you squeal like a pig, boy,â€ which appellant took to mean they were going to rape him.Â  
Appellant grabbed the gun from Shane and began shooting.Â  When it was over, he pushed the bodies out of the truck and put the second magazine in the gun because he thought someone else may have been out in the field.Â  A shot went off outside the truck.Â  Finally, appellant drove off in Shaneâ€™s truck.Â  He went to pick up his wife and his father because he was afraid Ronnie would hurt them.Â  After parking Shaneâ€™s truck at his fatherâ€™s house, appellant went to the police.
Sheriff Taylor was called as a defense witness.Â  He testified that Ronnie, who was now deceased, was at one time an international drug smuggler in cocaine and marijuana with connections to violent drug lords.Â  On cross-examination, Sheriff Taylor stated that Ronnie was very careful in his dealings.Â  The solicitor then asked, â€œDid you ever uncover anything that showed that Shane and Stacy were on (sic) any of this inside circle that Ronnie Burkhart would have trusted them?â€Â  Sheriff Taylor answered â€œno.â€Â  In reply, the defense sought to elicit Sheriff Taylorâ€™s testimony that Shane had been arrested for buying a sixteenth of an ounce of methamphetamine from an undercover agent in December 1995, two years before the killings.Â  The solicitor objected on the ground of relevance and the trial judge excluded the evidence.Â  Appellant claims the exclusion of this evidence prejudiced him because it indicated a relationship between the brothers and Ronnie that would substantiate his claim of self-defense.Â  We disagree.
Sheriff Taylor testified Ronnie Burkhart was out of the drug business by 1991, Ronnie did not deal in methamphetamine, and he knew of no connection between Shaneâ€™s 1995 drug transaction and Ronnie.Â  In the absence of any evidence linking Shaneâ€™s drug transaction to Ronnie, the excluded evidence did not tend to make more or less probable appellantâ€™s claim that Shane would have worked for Ronnie as a hit man.Â  See Rule 401, SCRE (evidence is relevant if it tends to make the existence of any fact at issue more or less probable).Â  We find the exclusion of this evidence could not reasonably have affected the outcome of the trial.Â  See State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 609 S.E.2d 520 (2005) (exclusion of evidence is not reversible error if it could not reasonably have affected outcome of trial).Â  
2.Â  Admission of evidence in sentencing phase
During the sentencing phase of trial, appellant objected to testimony by Stateâ€™s witness James Sligh, Director of Inmate Classification for the Department of Corrections, regarding the privileges available to an inmate who receives a sentence of life without parole.Â  These privileges include access to the yard, work, education, meals, canteen, phone, library, recreation, mail, television, and outside visitors.Â  On cross-examination, Sligh acknowledged that prison life is â€œvery regimentedâ€ and â€œis not a country club.â€Â  Further, appellant presented evidence through his own witness that prison is a harsh environment with violent predators where oneâ€™s freedom is severely curtailed.Â  
We have long held that evidence in the sentencing phase of a capital trial must be relevant to the character of the defendant or the circumstances of the crime.Â  State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 300 S.E.2d 63 (1982).Â  The juryâ€™s sole function is to make a sentencing determination based on these factors and not to legislate a plan of punishment.Â  State v. Johnson, 293 S.C. 321, 360 S.E.2d 317 (1987).Â  â€œSuch determinations as the time, place, manner, and conditions of execution or incarceration . . . are reserved . . . to agencies other than the jury.â€Â  State v. Plath (Plath II), 281 S.C. 1, 15, 313 S.E.2d 619, 627 (1984) (emphasis added).Â  Based on this reasoning, we have disallowed defense evidence regarding the process of electrocution, State v. Plath (Plath I), 277 S.C. 126, 284 S.E.2d 221 (1981), and expert testimony regarding the deterrent effect of capital punishment.Â  State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 476 S.E.2d 903 (1996).
Recently, in State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 623 S.E.2d 378 (2005), the defendant challenged on appeal the admission of evidence regarding general prison conditions.Â  Although we found the issue was not preserved for review, we cautioned the State and the defense bar that such evidence is not relevant to the question of whether a defendant should be sentenced to death or life imprisonment.Â  366 S.C. at 498-99, 623 S.E.2d at 387.Â  
This case was tried before our decision in Bowman; however, we apply that reasoning here because it is consistent with our long-standing rule that evidence in the sentencing phase of a capital trial must be relevant to the character of the defendant or the circumstances of the crime.Â  We are aware of the tension between evidence regarding the defendantâ€™s adaptability to prison life, which is clearly admissible,[2] and this restriction on the admission of evidence regarding prison life in general.Â  We note, however, that evidence of the defendantâ€™s characteristics may include prison conditions if narrowly tailored to demonstrate the defendantâ€™s personal behavior in those conditions.Â  
Here, unlike Bowman, appellant objected to the Stateâ€™s evidence regarding general prison conditions.Â  Although appellant attempted to counter the testimony of the Stateâ€™s witness with evidence regarding the harshness of prison life, this entire subject matter injected an arbitrary factor into the juryâ€™s sentencing considerations. Â A capital jury may not impose a death sentence under the influence of any arbitrary factor.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1) (2003).Â  When the jury is invited to speculate about irrelevant matters upon which a death sentence may be based, Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1) is violated.Â  State v. Sloan, 278 S.C. 435, 298 S.E.2d 92 (1982).Â  Accordingly, we reverse appellantâ€™s death sentence and remand for resentencing.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; REMANDED.
WALLER, J, concurs. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which BURNETT, J., concurs.


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in the majorityâ€™s conclusion that appellant is entitled to a new sentencing proceeding.Â  I write separately because I believe a violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1) (2003) is not subject to a harmless error analysis.
I agree with the majority that the prison conditions testimony by Mr. Sligh violated our rule that evidence in the sentencing phase of a capital trial must be relevant to the character of the defendant or the circumstances of the crime.Â  More importantly, this inadmissible evidence infused an arbitrary factor into the juryâ€™s decision to return a death sentence.Â  Once an arbitrary matter has been presented to the jury, this Court cannot uphold the death sentence if we are to fulfill our statutory duty under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1).Â  State v. Shaw, 273 S.C. 194, 209-210, 255 S.E.2d 799, 807 (1979), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).
The dissent argues that the statuteâ€™s prohibition against imposing a death sentence obtained under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor merely recites the requirements of the Eighth Amendment.Â  As a result, although not finding the evidence in this case to introduce an arbitrary subject to the jury, the dissent would subject violations of Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1) to a harmless error analysis.[3]
In my opinion, this Court should not apply a standard of review for constitutional errors to statutory violations.Â  The dissent ignores the plain language of the statute, which requires this Court to â€œdetermine whether the sentence of death was imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1) (emphasis added).Â  We are not required to determine if appellantâ€™s cross-examination of Mr. Sligh was able to remedy any error.Â  Once improper evidence of any kind injects an arbitrary factor into the juryâ€™s consideration, this Court cannot uphold the death sentence under Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1).Â  Moreover, a review for harmless error is unnecessary because by definition, evidence that implicates an arbitrary factor is prejudicial.
We must honor the General Assembly's prerogative to establish the procedure which it deems necessary to the fair administration of the death penalty. Â Where the legislature requires this Court to review a death sentence for possible arbitrariness, that directive should be conscientiously honored. Â I would thus not engage in a harmless error analysis which could potentially uphold a death sentence returned under the influence of an arbitrary factor. Accordingly, I agree with the majorityâ€™s decision to reverse the death sentence and remand for resentencing.

Chief Justice Toal: I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the introduction of irrelevant evidence in a capital sentencing proceeding does not, in and of itself, warrant reversal of Appellantâ€™s death sentence.Â  
Although we cautioned in State v. Bowman that evidence relating to the conditions of incarceration should not be admitted during a capital sentencing proceeding, nothing in that case indicated a departure from the general rules governing appeals involving the admission of evidence or constitutional issues.Â  See 366 S.C. 485, 498-99, 623 S.E.2d 378, 385 (2005).Â  With this principle in mind, I believe our jurisprudence requires clarification.
That evidentiary appeals in criminal trials and questions of fundamental fairness sometimes overlap must be an easy conclusion.Â  Even the most cursory review of this Courtâ€™s jurisprudence and federal precedent in the capital arena reveals as much.Â  Arguments in capital cases involving the introduction of evidence will invariably be buttressed by considerations of fundamental fairness secured by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.Â  In these cases, both the evidentiary questions of state law and the federal constitutional questions are of paramount importance.Â  Accordingly, a genuine resolution requires that these issues be given a complete discussion.
A trial court has a great deal of latitude concerning rulings on the admissibility of evidence, and a trial courtâ€™s ruling on such an issue will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion and a demonstration of prejudice. State v. Plath, 281 S.C. 1, 9-10, 313 S.E.2d 619, 624 (1984); State v. Gregory, 198 S.C. 98, 103, 16 S.E.2d 532, 534 (1941).Â  
In this case, although the trial court admitted irrelevant evidence during Appellantâ€™s sentencing proceeding, I can find no evidence indicating that the introduction of this evidence prejudiced Appellant.Â  Although the State improperly introduced evidence regarding the general conditions that Appellant would experience while in prison, Appellant cross-examined the Stateâ€™s witness at length and demonstrated that the conditions of Appellantâ€™s imprisonment would be quite severe.Â  Specifically, Appellant was able to inform the jury that, if he was spared the death penalty, he would be subject to the second highest degree of restriction in South Carolinaâ€™s prison system for the remainder of his life.[4]Â  In short, though this evidence was irrelevant and improper, Appellant used the evidence quite effectively to argue against imposing the death penalty.Â  Absent a showing of prejudice which resulted from the introduction of this evidence, our standards of review require us to affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision.[5] 
Turning to the questions of federal law, the Eighth Amendment is violated when the decision to impose the death penalty is made in an arbitrary manner, or â€œout of a whim, passion, prejudice, or mistake.â€Â  Caldwell v. Mississippi, 472 U.S. 320, 329-30 (1985); State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 587, 300 S.E.2d 63, 72 (1982).Â  Violations of the Fourteenth Amendment occur when something â€œso infects the trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.â€Â  See Darden v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 168, 181 (1986).Â  Furthermore, an appellate courtâ€™s inquiry does not end upon finding that a constitutional violation occurred.Â  Very recently, the United States Supreme Court reminded us that harmless error analysis is a constitutionally sufficient rubric by which an appellate court may judge whether most constitutional violations require reversal in a criminal case.Â  Washington v. Recuenco, 548 U.S. Â­Â­Â­__, 126 S.Ct. 2546, 2551 (2006).
In this case, I would not reach the question of whether the trial courtâ€™s error in admitting the above described evidence was harmless because I would find no constitutional violations occurred.Â  As a first matter, Appellant did not raise any constitutional objections in the trial court, and it is not clear that he raises these issues here.[6]Â  Assuming, however, that Appellant makes such arguments, in my view, the introduction of this improper evidence did not create an impermissible risk that the jury would make the decision to impose the death penalty in an arbitrary manner, nor did it so infect Appellantâ€™s sentencing proceeding with prejudice as to render it fundamentally unfair.[7]Â  Again, because I would find that no constitutional violations resulted from the introduction of this evidence, I do not believe this Court need decide whether any evidentiary error was harmless.
In my view, the majorityâ€™s resolution of this issue is controlled by a theme found largely in dicta beginning in State v. Woomer.Â  In that case, this Court stated â€œ[w]hen a solicitorâ€™s personal opinion is explicitly injected into the juryâ€™s deliberations as though it were in itself evidence justifying a sentence of death, the resulting death sentence may not be free from the influence of any arbitrary factor as required by S.C. Code Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1), and by the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution.â€Â  277 S.C. at 175, 284 S.E.2d at 359.Â  
I believe this Court has mistakenly seized upon the latter part of that statement and proceeded to treat Â§ 16-3-25(C) as providing a separate standard by which this Court should judge the conduct of capital sentencing proceedings.[8]Â  In my view, State v. Torrence all but openly rejects the argument that the statuteâ€™s prohibition of imposing a death sentence obtained under the influence of â€œpassion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor,â€ constitutes anything other than a recital of the Eighth Amendmentâ€™s requirements. Â See 305 S.C. at 68, 406 S.E.2d at 328.Â  Furthermore, in my view, the Eighth Amendmentâ€™s requirements are primarily concerned with the ultimate result in capital cases, which is â€œpreventing the imposition of excessive and disproportionate punishment upon the individual prisoner.â€Â  State v. Copeland, 378 S.C. 572, 590, 300 S.E.2d 63, 73-74 (1982).Â  Thus, even if Torrence did not reject this proposition, I would decline to view Â§ 16-3-25(C) as proscribing a standard of review that is independent from the Eighth Amendment.Â  Instead, I would interpret the statute to prohibit the imposition of the death penalty only in those situations where it would offend the Constitution.Â  In my view, a separate standard is not necessary.[9]
Our pronouncement disfavoring this evidence in Bowman was nothing new.Â  See Plath, 281 S.C. at 15, 313 S.E.2d at 627 (â€œIt should not be necessary in the near future . . . to remind the bench and bar of the strict focus to be maintained in the course of a capital sentencing trial.â€); and Smart, 278 S.C. at 526, 299 S.E.2d at 692-93 (â€œWhile this Court approves zealous representation . . . it is important in capital cases to maintain strict focus upon the particular characteristics of the specific crime and the unique attributes of the defendant.â€).Â  In reversing this case, I believe we treat the disapproval of this type of evidence as though it were a novel development, and that we unnecessarily depart from an established course of analysis that is easily tied to defined doctrines.Â  In my view, reversing Appellantâ€™s sentence uses Bowman to propagate a rule that inappropriately presumes prejudice in many cases and is unjustified given the existing constitutional framework.[10]
The majority and concurrence presume what they purport to establish, which is that Â§ 16-3-25(C)(1) requires reversal when improper evidence is introduced in a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  Were that the General Assemblyâ€™s intention, I believe it surely would have spoken in terms of an arbitrary factorâ€™s â€œpresenceâ€ instead of its â€œinfluence.â€Â  Appellate courts are ill-equipped to speculate about the influence improperly admitted evidence might have exerted on a juryâ€™s determination.Â  Therefore, in my view, the most prudent course in these cases is to tie the statutory review requirement to the established guideposts provided by the relevant constitutional jurisprudence.Â  Today, the majority and concurrence endorse a rule that is markedly stricter than the constitution requires, is contrary to at least two of this Courtâ€™s prior decisions, and plays far too loosely with the language of the statute. 
For these reasons, I would hold that the trial court erred in admitting evidence relating to the conditions of incarceration during Appellantâ€™s capital sentencing proceeding, but I would affirm Appellantâ€™s death sentence.
BURNETT, J., concurs.

[1]Shaneâ€™s unloaded hunting rifle was found under the truckâ€™s back seat beneath a large speaker.Â  In Sonyaâ€™s purse were two unopened pocketknives, and Shane had an unopened knife in his pants pocket.Â Â  
[2]See generally Skipper v. South Carolina, 476 U.S. 1 (1986) (evidence of good behavior in prison admissible in mitigation as relevant to future adaptability); State v. Schafer, 352 S.C. 191, 573 S.E.2d 796 (2002) (evidence of violent behavior in prison relevant to future dangerousness); State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996) (defendantâ€™s future dangerousness and his adaptability to prison life are legitimate interests in the penalty phase of a capital case). 
[3] This Court has acknowledged the appropriateness of harmless error analysis in capital cases where a defendantâ€™s constitutional rights are violated.Â  See Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 430 S.E.2d 834 (1992).
[4] Eight pages of the record contain the Stateâ€™s expertâ€™s direct testimony. Appellantâ€™s cross-examination of this expert fills twenty pages of the record.
[5] Plath further underscores my point. Â In that case, this Court unanimously affirmed a death sentence because these precise errors were not accompanied by any demonstration of prejudice.Â  See 281 S.C. at 9-10, 313 S.E.2d at 624.
[6] At trial, Appellant objected that this testimony was improper under this Courtâ€™s ruling in Plath.Â  That case contains no material discussion of the Eighth or Fourteenth Amendments.Â  Plathâ€™s discussion of this type of evidence is best interpreted as resolving a traditional appeal of a question of the admission of evidence.Â  See 281 S.C at 14-16, 313 S.E.2d at 627.Â  
[7] In making this determination, I judge the effect of these evidentiary errors in the context of the entire record.Â  See State v. Woomer, 277 S.C. 170, 174-75, 284 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1981). 
[8] This principle has consistently re-appeared in our precedent.Â  See Thompson v. Aiken, 281 S.C. 239, 240, 315 S.E.2d 110, 110 (1984); State v. Sloan, 278 S.C. 435, 438, 298 S.E.2d 92, 93 (1982); State v. Smart, 278 S.C. 515, 517, 299 S.E.2d 686, 687 (1982) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 70, 406 S.E.2d 315, 329 (1991)); and State v. Butler, 277 S.C. 543, 544, 290 S.E.2d 420, 420 (1982) (overruled on other grounds by Torrence, 305 S.C. at 70, 406 S.E.2d at 329).
[9] I do not necessarily question the holdings in the cases I have cited, only the reasoning.Â  Any number of errors can infect a trial with unfairness to such a degree as to violate the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.Â  These include (1) the introduction of overly inflammatory evidence and (2) arguments which impermissibly appeal to the passions or prejudices of a jury.
[10] Coincidentally, the view taken by the concurrence is contrary to our opinion in Bowman and seems to embrace a rekindled form of Â­in favorem vitae review. Â This view, if applied in Bowman, would surely have commanded the Court to at least deal with the merits of Bowmanâ€™s claim regarding this â€œprison conditionsâ€ testimony rather than disposing of his claim on error preservation grounds.Â  See 366 S.C. at 498, 623 S.E.2d at 385.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Carlton D. Robinson, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26244Â Â  
Submitted November 14, 2006 - Filed January 8, 2007

PUBLIC REPRIMAND 


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel and C. Tex Davis, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Jason B. Buffkin, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 
PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the Agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.
Facts
In 2005, respondent was contacted by National Real Estate Information Services (NREIS) about handling closings of residential real estate transactions in South Carolina.Â  Respondent closed approximately thirty transactions arranged by NREIS in 2005, all of which involved refinances except for the subject transaction, which was a purchase transaction.Â  
With regard to the subject transaction, respondent, after speaking with the complainant, declined to proceed with the closing.Â  As for the refinances, respondent represents that each was handled by him in substantially the same manner.Â  Respondent would typically receive the closing package a day in advance of the closing.Â  He did not prepare the title abstracts used in the closings.Â  Instead, he was informed by NREIS that they use other South Carolina attorneys to do the title work and obtain a certified legal opinion prior to closing.Â  Once a certified legal opinion was obtained, NREIS would forward the relevant closing materials to respondent for closing.Â  However, respondent took no affirmative action to verify NREISâ€™ representations nor did he ever obtain a copy of the certified legal opinions for the refinances.Â  Respondent represents that at each closing he reviewed all of the relevant documents, including the terms of the loan, with the client and that this process included a careful review of the Settlement Statement to confirm the clientâ€™s agreement with the costs and disbursements associated with the closing transaction.Â  At the conclusion of the closings, respondent forwarded the closing documents to NREIS.Â  He did not record the mortgage associated with any of the transactions nor did he take any affirmative action to confirm that the mortgages were properly recorded.Â  In addition, respondent had no involvement in the disbursement of funds to each client and did not take any action to confirm that the funds were disbursed as reflected in the Settlement Statement.
Respondent, who has no prior disciplinary history, has been forthright and cooperative with ODC throughout this investigation and maintains he is committed to the improvement of the management of his practice to insure full compliance with the guidelines governing real estate closings.Â 
Law
Respondent admits that his conduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers).Â  In addition, respondent admits he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 5.5(b) (lawyer shall not assist a person who is not a member of the bar in the performance of activity that constitutes the unauthorized practice of law); and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).
Conclusion
We find respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand. Accordingly, we accept the Agreement and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
Â PUBLIC REPRIMAND
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 In May 2005, Nationwide Appraisal contacted respondent to retain her services as closing attorney to handle the closing of a home equity line of credit for a client.Â  The closing occurred on May 9, 2005, at respondentâ€™s office.Â  Respondent received the closing documents and instructions from Nationwide Appraisal either the day before or the day of the closing.Â  Respondent did not prepare the closing documents or perform the title exam nor does she know the identity of the person who did so.Â  Respondent assumed that person was an attorney licensed in South Carolina or was supervised by such an attorney; however, she admits she took no affirmative action to verify this information.

Nationwide Appraisal paid respondent $200 for her services a few weeks after the closing; however, the HUD-1A Settlement Statement executed at the clientâ€™s closing does not reflect a payment to respondent.Â  The Settlement Statement does include a charge of $175 to Nationwide Appraisal for a settlement or closing fee, as well as a charge of $55 to GAC for an abstract or title search.[1]
Respondent has informed ODC that prior to the closing at issue, she handled several other closings for Nationwide Appraisal and those closings were handled in substantially the same manner as described above.Â  ODC has no information that anyone involved in these closings suffered any harm as a result of respondentâ€™s conduct.Â

Law
Respondent admits that her conduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers).Â  In addition, respondent admits she has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 5.5(b) (lawyer shall not assist a person who is not a member of the bar in the performance of activity that constitutes the unauthorized practice of law); and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).
Conclusion
We find respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand. Accordingly, we accept the Agreement and publicly reprimand respondent for her misconduct.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Kevin M. Cunningham, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26246 
Submitted November 14, 2006 - Filed January 8, 2007

PUBLIC REPRIMAND 


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Lourie A. Salley, III, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a sanction of an indefinite suspension or disbarment.Â  We accept the Agreement and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.
Facts
Respondent represented the personal representative of two estates.Â  Respondent used approximately $70,000 received and collected for the beneficiaries of the estates to pay his personal household, medical and business expenses.Â  Respondent hoped to use future income to repay the misappropriated funds.
Respondent also failed to comply with Rule 417, SCACR, by not maintaining separate trust and operating accounts and not reconciling his accounts.Â  As a result, respondent failed to hold funds of clients and third persons separate from his own.
Finally, respondent failed to diligently handle the estates and failed to adequately communicate with his client regarding the estates.Â  He also provided false information to his client regarding the estates in an attempt to conceal his misappropriation of estate funds.
Respondent self reported his misconduct to ODC and the solicitor and has been fully cooperative with ODC during the course of its investigation.Â  Respondent also consented to being placed on interim suspension.[1]Â  
In addition, respondent represents, by way of mitigation, but not as a defense, that he was diagnosed in December 2002 with germ cell cancer, his second bout with cancer, at the same time his wife gave birth to their second child.Â  Respondent underwent aggressive chemotherapy.Â  The cost of the medical bills associated with the birth of the child and respondentâ€™s treatment, along with the fact that respondent was unable to work full time during his treatment, financially devastated his family.
Law
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep a client reasonably informed about the status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of clients in the lawyerâ€™s possession in connection with a representation separate from the lawyer's own property); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(b) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to commit a criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving moral turpitude); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).
Respondent further admits his misconduct is grounds for discipline under the following provisions of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR: Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice, bring the courts or legal profession into disrepute, or demonstrating an unfitness to practice law); and Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the oath of office). Â In addition, respondent admits his misconduct violated Rule 417, SCACR.
    

Conclusion
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this state. Â Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.
Disbarred.
    
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Responsible Economic Development, Angela Ketchum, Carolyn Jebaily, Peggy Brown, Rachell Hyman, Bobby Griffin, Walter Sallenger, 
          its Members and Directors, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control and Wal-Mart Stores East, LP, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26248Â Â  
Heard December 5, 2006 - Filed January 22, 2007

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        Robert Guild, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Etta R. Williams, of Columbia, for Respondent South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control. 
        James D. Myrick, of Buist, Moore, Smythe & McGee, PA, of Charleston, for Respondent Wal-Mart Stores East, LP.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This appeal concerns the issuance of a stormwater management and sediment control permit (stormwater permit) to Respondent Wal-Mart Stores East, LP (Wal-Mart). Â We certified this case for review from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and affirm as modified the circuit courtâ€™s decision to uphold the issuance of the stormwater permit.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 2003, Wal-Mart applied for a stormwater permit in connection with a proposed development in Florence, South Carolina.Â  Wal-Martâ€™s proposed development includes the construction of a Wal-Mart Supercenter, an accompanying parking lot, and a central stormwater detention pond.Â  The stormwater would flow across the paved and landscaped areas to inlets, which would lead to the detention pond.Â  The detention pond would accommodate 2, 10, 25, 50, and 100-year frequency storm events.Â  From the detention pond, the stormwater would flow into an unnamed tributary and continue in the unnamed tributary for approximately one-half mile at which point the unnamed tributary converges with Jeffries Creek. 
Respondent South Carolina Department of Health and Environment Control (DHEC) granted the stormwater permit.Â  Responsible Economic Development, Angela Ketchum, Carolyn Jebaily, Peggy Brown, Rachell Hyman, Bobby Griffin, and Walter Sallenger, its Members and Directors, (Appellants) objected to the issuance of the stormwater permit and brought this contested case before an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).Â  At the hearing, Appellants argued 26 S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 72-305(B)(4) (Supp. 2005) required denial of the stormwater permit because Wal-Martâ€™s proposed development violated the antidegradation rules set forth in 25 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 61-68 and -69 (Supp. 2005).Â  The ALJ issued a Final Order and Decision upholding DHECâ€™s grant of a stormwater permit.
Appellants appealed to the Board of Health and Environment Control (Board), which affirmed the ALJâ€™s decision.Â  On further appeal, the circuit court upheld the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  This appeal followed.
ISSUE

  Did the circuit court err in affirming the Boardâ€™s decision to uphold the grant of a stormwater permit to Wal-Mart? 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
This case involves appearances before four tribunals.Â  The ALJ presided as the finder of fact at the contested hearing.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(B) (2005).Â  The Board sat in an appellate capacity, and its review was governed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(D).Â  The circuit court also sat in an appellate capacity, and its review was governed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6).
 This Court determines whether the circuit court properly applied its standard of review and applies the same standard of review established for the circuit court.Â  Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 512, 560 S.E.2d 410, 413 (2002).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify the decision of any agency if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the findings, conclusions, or decisions of the agency are:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (b) in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (c) made upon unlawful procedure;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (d) affected by other error of law;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (e) clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial  evidence on the whole record; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or  clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Act. No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants contend the circuit court erroneously affirmed the issuance of a stormwater permit in this case.Â  Appellants allege Regulation 72-305(B)(4) requires the denial of the stormwater permit because stormwater runoff from Wal-Martâ€™s proposed development will further depress oxygen levels in the unnamed tributary and Jeffries Creek and thus violates the antidegradation rules set forth in Regulations 61-68(D)(1) and -69.Â  Appellants also contend Regulation 72-305(B)(4) requires the denial of the stormwater permit because Wal-Mart has failed to employ adequate measures to handle pollutants discharged from the development as required by Regulation 61-68(D)(2) and DHECâ€™s written policy regarding antidegradation.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, Bureau of Water, Antidegradation for Activities Contributing Nonpoint Source Pollution to Impaired Waters (Nov. 1999).Â  We disagree.Â  
The Stormwater Management and Sediment Reduction Act (Stormwater Act)[1] requires a person who intends to engage in a land disturbing activity[2] to submit a stormwater management and sediment control plan to the appropriate agency and obtain a permit before engaging in the activity, unless an exemption applies.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-14-30 (Supp. 2005).Â  The Stormwater Act further requires DHEC to promulgate regulations for the â€œtypes of activities that require a stormwater . . . permitâ€ and for â€œpermit application and approval requirements.â€Â  Id. Â§ 48-14-50(C)(3) & (9).Â  DHEC fulfilled that duty by promulgating, in relevant part, Regulations 72-305 and -307.Â  Regulation 72-305 outlines the permit application and approval procedure, and Regulation 72-307 sets forth the minimum standards and specifications and the specific design criteria for projects requiring a stormwater management and sediment control plan.Â  
Regulation 72-305(B)(3) requires Regulations 72-305 and -307 to apply to land disturbing activities disturbing more than five acres.Â  DHEC can modify the regulatory requirements of Regulations 72-305 and -307 â€œon a case-by-case basis to address specific stormwater quantity or quality problems or to meet S.C. Coastal Council or other regulatory requirements.â€[3] 26 S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 72-305(B)(4).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The ALJ determined the requirements of Regulations 72-305 and -307 applied to this case because Wal-Martâ€™s proposed development involves a land disturbing activity covering approximately 43 acres.Â  He found the stormwater runoff from Wal-Martâ€™s development would not flow directly into Jeffries Creek, an impaired water body, but would flow directly into an unnamed tributary, which is an unimpaired water body.Â  Then the stormwater would flow for one-half mile before converging with Jeffries Creek, and he determined the stormwater runoff would obtain re-aeration properties before converging with Jeffries Creek.Â  The ALJ found stormwater runoff from three other commercial developments flowed into the unnamed tributary before converging with Jeffries Creek without negatively affecting the water quality of Jeffries Creek.Â  He also found there was no significant evidence that quantified the inadequate measures alleged by Appellants.Â  Based on the totality of the circumstances, the ALJ determined Regulation 72-305(B)(4) was not applicable to Wal-Martâ€™s application for a stormwater permit and upheld the issuance of the stormwater permit to Wal-Mart.Â  
The Board affirmed the ALJâ€™s decision.Â  The circuit court found the Boardâ€™s view of the antidegradation rules conformed to the framework set forth in Regulations 61-68 and -69 and found there was substantial evidence to support the ALJâ€™s and the Boardâ€™s findings.Â  
Appellants allege Wal-Martâ€™s proposed development violates regulations promulgated pursuant to the Pollution Control Act.[4]Â  The purpose of the Pollution Control Act is â€œto maintain reasonable standards of purity of the air and water resources of the State. . . .â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-1-20 (1987). Â DHEC has the â€œauthority to abate, control and prevent pollutionâ€ in order to enforce the provisions of the Pollution Control Act.Â  Id.Â  DHEC is also authorized to issue permits pursuant to the Pollution Control Act for discharge of wastes or air contaminants and for construction or alteration of disposal systems.Â  Id. Â§Â§ 48-1-100 & -110 (Supp. 2005).Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â  
Although stormwater runoff is a source of pollution,[5] the legislature enacted the Stormwater Act to specifically deal with stormwater management and sediment reduction.Â  The purpose of the Stormwater Act is â€œto reduce the adverse effects of stormwater runoff and sediment and to safeguard property and the public welfare by strengthening and making uniform the existing stormwater management and sediment control program.â€Â  Act No. 51, 1991 Acts 167.Â  The Stormwater Act requires DHEC to issue permits for persons engaging in a land disturbing activity, unless an exemption applies.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-14-30(A).Â Â Â  
As a creature of statutes, regulatory bodies like DHEC have only the authority granted them by the legislature.  Med. Socâ€™y of S.C. v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 334 S.C. 270, 275, 513 S.E.2d 352, 355 (1999); City of Columbia v. Bd. of Health & Envtl. Control, 292 S.C. 199, 202, 355 S.E.2d 536, 538 (1987).Â  Any action taken by DHEC outside of its statutory and regulatory authority is null and void.Â  Triska v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 292 S.C. 190, 194, 355 S.E.2d 531, 533 (1987).Â  
Relevant to this appeal, the regulations of the Pollution Control Actâ€”Regulations 61-68 and -69[6]â€”and the regulations of the Stormwater Actâ€”Regulations 72-305 and -307[7]â€”do not reference each other and are authorized by different enabling acts.Â  In the absence of statutory authorization to apply the two acts and their corresponding regulations to each other, the regulations of the Pollution Control Act do not apply to the Stormwater Act or its regulations.Â  Accordingly, we conclude, as a matter of law, the case-by-case modification of regulatory requirements under the Stormwater Act cannot be invoked because of an alleged violation of the Pollution Control Actâ€™s regulations.Â  Furthermore, a stormwater permit issued pursuant to the Stormwater Act cannot be denied based on the regulations of the Pollution Control Act.Â  Therefore, Regulation 72-305(B)(4) does not require the denial of a stormwater permit on the ground that the antidegradation rules have been violated because the regulations of the Pollution Control Act do not apply to the Stormwater Act.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing analysis, we affirm as modified the decision to grant a stormwater permit to Wal-Mart.
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 48-14-10 to -170 (Supp. 2005).
[2] Â â€œâ€˜Land disturbing activityâ€™ means any use of the land by any person that results in a change in the natural cover or topography that may cause erosion and contribute to sediment and alter the quality and quantity of the stormwater runoff.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-14-20(8).
[3] Â See generally S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-14-20(11) (defining â€œ[s]tormwater managementâ€ to mean for: â€œ(a) quantitative control, a system of vegetative or structural measures, or both, that control the increased volume and rate of stormwater runoff caused by manmade changes to the land; (b) qualitative control, a system of vegetative, structural, or other measures that reduce or eliminate pollutants that might otherwise be carried by stormwater runoffâ€).
[4] Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 48-1-10 to -350 (1987 & Supp. 2005).
[5]Â  See generally 26 S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 72-300(A) (Supp. 2005) (â€œStormwater runoff is a source of pollution of waters of the State.â€).
[6]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 48-1-10 to -350.
[7]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 48-14-10 to -170.
