description: The Court reversed the PCR courtâ€™s finding that plea counsel rendered ineffective assistance of counsel.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Creuncle D. Suber, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Newberry County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26249 Â Â Â 
Submitted December 7, 2006 - Filed January 22, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Julie M. Thames, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Offense of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the grant of post-conviction relief (PCR) to Creuncle D. Suber (Respondent).  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 9, 2002, Respondent drove away from a convenience store in Newberry, South Carolina without paying for gasoline.Â  The store clerk reported the incident, including a description of the car and of Respondent, to the county sheriffâ€™s department.Â  Lieutenant Wesley Boland responded to the call.Â  When he saw Respondent driving a car matching the store clerkâ€™s description, he activated his blue lights and siren, but Respondent did not stop.Â  Respondent continued driving until he entered a dead-end dirt road.Â  At the dead end, Respondent turned around in a driveway, and Lieutenant Boland attempted to block Respondent from exiting the driveway.Â  According to Lieutenant Boland, Respondent collided with the officerâ€™s vehicle, and this collision provided Respondent enough space to maneuver out of the driveway and continue his escape.Â  Respondent subsequently wrecked his car and continued his flight on foot.Â  Lieutenant Boland pursued Respondent, a struggle ensued, and Respondent was eventually apprehended.Â  
Respondent pled guilty to failure to stop for a blue light and no contest to assault and battery with intent to kill (ABWIK) and to resisting arrest with a deadly weapon.Â  He was sentenced to fourteen yearsâ€™ imprisonment for ABWIK, ten years for resisting arrest with a deadly weapon, and three years for failing to stop, to be served concurrently.Â  
Respondent filed this application for PCR, alleging plea counsel was ineffective for failing to advise him that assault with intent to kill (AWIK) was a lesser-included offense of ABWIK.Â  At the PCR hearing, Respondent testified Lieutenant Boland hit his car in an attempt to stop Respondent from fleeing, and he testified he never attempted to hit the officer with his car.Â  Respondent also submitted into evidence pictures of his car after the incident, which Respondent alleged showed the officer hit his car.Â  He further testified plea counsel advised him there were no lesser-included offenses to any of his charges, but if he had known a jury could consider AWIK, he would have insisted on proceeding to trial rather than pleading guilty. 
Also at the PCR hearing, plea counsel testified although there were extensive plea negotiations, the negotiations failed and he proceeded to prepare for trial.Â  Plea counsel testified he was prepared for trial, but on the day of trial, Respondent chose to plead guilty and no contest to the charges.Â  He also testified he was likely surprised by Respondentâ€™s decision to plead guilty on the day of trial because he had told the plea judge he had stayed up late preparing for trial.Â  Plea counsel conceded he did not discuss AWIK as a lesser-included offense of ABWIK with Respondent.Â  Plea counsel denied he told Respondent there were no lesser-included offenses for any of the charges because plea counsel alleged they never discussed lesser-included offenses.Â  He also testified if Respondent had gone to trial and the evidence presented at trial required the jury to be instructed on a lesser-included offense, he would have requested such a charge. 
The PCR judge found plea counsel was deficient for failing to advise Respondent of lesser-included offenses including AWIK.Â  The PCR judge also found Respondent was prejudiced by this deficiency and granted Respondent a new trial.Â  
ISSUE
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the PCR judge err in granting Respondent a new trial based on  ineffective assistance of counsel?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000).Â  There is a two-prong test for evaluating claims of ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  First, a PCR applicant must show that his counselâ€™s performance was deficient such that it falls below an objective standard of reasonableness.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687, 104 S.Ct. 2052, 2064, 80 L.Ed.2d 674, 693 (1984); Alexander v. State, 303 S.C. 539, 541, 402 S.E.2d 484, 485 (1991).Â  Second, an applicant must show there is a reasonable probability, but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been different.Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 687, 104 S.Ct. at 2064, 80 L.Ed.2d at 693; Alexander, 303 S.C. at 541-42, 402 S.E.2d at 485.Â  Where there has been a guilty plea, the applicant must prove prejudice by showing that, but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability he would not have pleaded guilty and instead would have insisted on going to trial.Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 59, 106 S.Ct. 366, 370, 88 L.Ed.2d 203, 210 (1985); Jordan v. State, 297 S.C. 52, 54, 374 S.E.2d 683, 684 (1988).Â  In determining guilty plea issues, it is proper to consider the guilty plea transcript as well as evidence at the PCR hearing.Â  Harres v. Leeke, 282 S.C. 131, 133, 318 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1984). 
This Court will uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of probative value to support them.Â  Caprood, 338 S.C. at 109-10, 525 S.E.2d at 517.Â  This Court will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 651, 594 S.E.2d 462, 465 (2004).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues the PCR judge erred in finding plea counselâ€™s performance was deficient.Â  The State contends plea counsel rendered reasonably effective assistance to Respondent despite the fact plea counsel did not advise Respondent that AWIK was a lesser-included offense of ABWIK because AWIK was not a viable lesser-included offense under these facts and circumstances.Â  We agree.Â  
ABWIK is an unlawful act of violent nature to the person of another with malice aforethought, either express or implied.Â  ABWIK is commonly described as the following: if the victim had died from the injury, the defendant would have been guilty of murder.Â  State v. Sutton, 340 S.C. 393, 396, 532 S.E.2d 283, 285 (2000).Â  In comparison, the elements of AWIK are: (1) an unlawful attempt; (2) to commit a violent injury; (3) to the person of another; (4) with malicious intent; and (5) accompanied by the present ability to complete the act.Â  State v. Burton, 356 S.C 259, 264, 589 S.E.2d 6, 8 (2003).
The trial court is required to charge a jury on a lesser-included offense â€œif there is any evidence from which it could be inferred the lesser, rather than the greater, offense was committed.â€Â  State v. Gourdine, 322 S.C. 396, 398, 472 S.E.2d 241, 242 (1996).Â  However, the trial court should refuse to charge on a lesser-included offense where there is no evidence that the defendant committed the lesser rather than the greater offense.Â  State v. Smith, 315 S.C. 547, 549, 446 S.E.2d 411, 413 (1994).Â  
Respondent testified he did not attempt to nor did he hit Lieutenant Bolandâ€™s vehicle.Â  Further, Respondent testified he did not intend to harm or kill Lieutenant Boland, but he intended to flee from the officer.Â  Given Respondentâ€™s testimony, he did not have the requisite intent to satisfy the offense of AWIK.Â  Instead, Respondentâ€™s testimony indicates a jury may have found him not guilty of ABWIK.Â  Furthermore, the evidence indicates there was a collision, and although there may have been a jury issue as to which person struck the otherâ€™s vehicle, there was no dispute that a battery occurred.Â  This evidence is insufficient to suggest Respondent was only guilty of AWIK.Â  See generally State v. Funchess, 267 S.C. 427, 429, 229 S.E.2d 331, 332 (1976) (â€œ[I]t is not error to refuse to submit a lesser included offense unless there is testimony tending to show that the defendant is only guilty of the lesser offense.â€).Â  Therefore, plea counsel was not deficient for failing to advise Respondent of AWIK because Respondent failed to present any evidence that would have entitled him to a charge for AWIK under these facts.Â  Compare Kerrigan v. State, 304 S.C. 561, 563-64, 406 S.E.2d 160, 161-62 (1991) (finding there was evidence in the record that PCR applicant was only guilty of lesser-included offense and holding PCR counsel was ineffective in failing to advise applicant of lesser offense before pleading guilty); see generally Sellers v. State, 362 S.C. 182, 607 S.E.2d 82 (2005) (reversing grant of relief where PCR judge found ineffective assistance of counsel for failure to request jury charges on lesser-included offenses because there was no evidence in the record to support jury charges for lesser-included offenses); Magazine v. State, 361 S.C. 610, 606 S.E.2d 761 (2004) (reversing PCR judgeâ€™s grant of relief where the record was devoid of any evidence warranting a jury charge on the lesser offense).Â  
CONCLUSION
No evidence of probative value supports the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that plea counsel was deficient under these facts.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s grant of a new trial. 
REVERSED.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI 

Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26250Â Â Â  
Submitted September 20, 2006 - Filed January 22, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Walter H. Hinton, II, of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, LLP, of Greenville; and Aisha S. Lusk, of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, LLP, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This is a post-conviction relief (PCR) case.Â  The PCR judge granted relief to William R. Talley (Respondent).Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition for writ of certiorari and reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
 In 1995, Respondent pled guilty to possession of drug paraphernalia in magistrateâ€™s court and paid a $200 fine.Â  In 1996, he pled guilty to criminal domestic violence also in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  Respondent received a $940 fine and was sentenced to thirty daysâ€™ imprisonment, immediately suspended on the condition of six monthsâ€™ good behavior.Â  In 2003, Respondent filed this PCR application to set aside the two misdemeanor convictions alleging his federal constitutional right to counsel had been violated because he was not represented by counsel in either conviction.Â  
Respondent is currently serving a 97-month federal sentence for conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute and distribution of cocaine and cocaine base.Â  He was assessed two criminal history points for the two state convictions under the United States Sentencing Guidelines.Â  Respondent contends his federal sentence was enhanced by approximately ten months because of these criminal history points.Â  
The State moved to summarily dismiss Respondentâ€™s PCR application for failure to file within the statute of limitations pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003).[1]Â  Respondent argued his PCR application was timely filed under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(B)[2] because it was filed within one year of Alabama v. Shelton, 535 U.S. 654, 122 S.Ct. 1764, 152 L.Ed.2d 888 (2002).Â  
The PCR judge denied the motion to dismiss and held Respondent had timely filed his PCR application under Â§ 17-27-45(B) because Shelton created a new rule that must be applied retroactively on collateral review.Â  The PCR judge determined, under Shelton, the constitutional right to counsel applied to Respondentâ€™s convictions and Respondent had not waived the right.Â  The PCR judge concluded Respondentâ€™s right to counsel had been violated in both convictions and vacated Respondentâ€™s convictions. 
ISSUE

  Did the PCR judge err in applying Alabama v. Shelton, 535 U.S. 654, 122 S.Ct. 1764, 152 L.Ed.2d 888 (2002), retroactively on collateral review to Respondentâ€™s convictions?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
A PCR applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000).Â  The Court will uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of probative value to support them.Â  Id. at 109-10, 525 S.E.2d at 517.Â  The Court will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues the PCR judge erred in applying Shelton retroactively on collateral review to Respondentâ€™s convictions.Â  We conclude the PCR judge correctly determined Shelton must be applied retroactively on collateral review, but erroneously applied Shelton to Respondentâ€™s convictions.Â  
The State urges us to apply both Teague v. Lane, 489 U.S. 288, 109 S.Ct. 1060, 103 L.Ed.2d 334 (1989), and State v. Jones, 312 S.C. 100, 439 S.E.2d 282 (1994), to determine whether Shelton should be applied retroactively on collateral review.Â  We disagree.Â  In determining whether Respondent was deprived of his federal constitutional right to counsel, we are required to follow the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s decisions on retroactivity.Â  Am. Trucking Assâ€™ns, Inc. v. Smith, 496 U.S. 167, 178, 110 S.Ct. 2323, 2330, 110 L.Ed.2d 148, 159 (1990) (â€œIn order to ensure the uniform application of decisions construing constitutional requirements and to prevent States from denying or curtailing federally protected rights, we have consistently required that state courts adhere to our retroactivity decisions.â€); see also, e.g., State v. Means, 367 S.C. 374, 626 S.E.2d 348 (2006) (applying Jones in determining State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005), should be applied retroactively); State v. Hill, 361 S.C. 297, 604 S.E.2d 696 (2004) (applying Jones in determining State v. Sutton, 340 S.C. 393, 532 S.E.2d 283 (2000), should be applied retroactively); Gibson v. State, 355 S.C. 429, 586 S.E.2d 119 (2003) (applying Teague to determine whether Sandstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S. 510, 99 S.Ct. 2450, 61 L.Ed.2d 39 (1979), should be applied retroactively on collateral review).Â  
In general, the question of whether a decision announcing a new rule should be given prospective or retroactive effect should be addressed at the time of the decision.Â  Teague, 489 U.S. at 300, 109 S.Ct. at 1070, 103 L.Ed.2d at 349.Â  â€œ[A] case announces a new rule when it breaks new ground or imposes a new obligation on the States or the Federal Government.Â  To put it differently, a case announces a new rule if the result was not dictated Â Â Â Â  by precedent existing at the time the defendantâ€™s conviction became Â Â  final.â€Â  Id. at 301, 109 S.Ct. at 1070, 103 L.Ed.2d at 349 (internal citations omitted) (emphasis in original).Â  
In Shelton, the Supreme Court held the constitutional right to counsel extends to a defendant who receives a â€œsuspended sentence that may â€˜end up in the actual deprivation of a personâ€™s liberty.â€™â€Â  535 U.S. at 658, 122 S.Ct. at 1767, 152 L.Ed.2d at 895 (citing Argersinger v. Hamlin, 407 U.S. 25, 40, 92 S.Ct. 2006, 2014, 32 L.Ed.2d 530, 540 (1972)).[3]Â  The Supreme Court explained: 

  A suspended sentence is a prison term imposed for the offense of Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  conviction.Â  Once the prison term is triggered, the defendant is Â Â Â  incarcerated not for the probation violation, but for the underlying Â Â Â  offense.Â  The uncounseled conviction at that point â€œresult[s] in Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  imprisonment. . .;â€ it â€œends up in the actual deprivation of a personâ€™s Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  liberty.â€Â  

Shelton, 535 U.S. at 662, 122 S.Ct. at 1770, 152 L.Ed.2d at 898 (citing Nichols v. United States, 511 U.S. 738, 746, 114 S.Ct. 1921, 1927, 128 L.Ed.2d 745, 754 (1994) and Argersinger, 407 U.S. at 40, 92 S.Ct. at 2014, 32 L.Ed.2d at 540). Â Â 
The Supreme Court asserted that two prior decisions, Argersinger and Scott v. Illinois, 440 U.S. 367, 99 S.Ct. 1158, 59 L.Ed.2d 383 (1979), controlled its decision in Shelton.Â  535 U.S. at 657, 122 S.Ct. at 1767, 152 L.Ed.2d at 895.Â  In Argersinger the Supreme Court held â€œthat absent a knowing and intelligent waiver, no person may be imprisoned for any offense, whether classified as petty, misdemeanor, or felony, unless he was represented by counsel at trial.â€Â  407 U.S. at 37, 92 S.Ct. at 2012, 32 L.Ed.2d at 538 (clarifying the scope of Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335, 83 S.Ct. 792, 9 L.Ed.2d 799 (1963), in which the Supreme Court held that the Sixth Amendmentâ€™s guarantee of the right of an indigent defendant to appointed counsel applies to state criminal prosecutions through the Fourteenth Amendment).Â  Then in Scott, the Supreme Court noted â€œthe central premise of Argersinger - that actual imprisonment is a penalty different in kind from fines or the mere threat of imprisonment - is eminently sound and warrants adoption of actual imprisonment as the line defining the constitutional right to appointment of counsel.â€Â  440 U.S. at 373, 99 S.Ct. at 1162, 59 L.Ed.2d at 389.Â  The Supreme Court found the constitutional right to counsel does not apply when a prison term is an authorized punishment but not actually imposed. Â Id. at 369, 99 S.Ct. at 1160, 59 L.Ed.2d at 386.
Although the Supreme Court in Shelton found the Argersinger-Scott â€œactual imprisonmentâ€ rule controlling, â€œthe fact that a court says that its decision is within the â€˜logical compassâ€™ of an earlier decision, or indeed that it is â€˜controlledâ€™ by a prior decision, is not conclusive for purposes of deciding whether the current decision is a â€˜new ruleâ€™ under Teague.â€Â  Butler v. McKellar, 494 U.S. 407, 415, 110 S.Ct. 1212, 1217, 108 L.Ed.2d 347, 356 (1990).Â  Precedent prior to Shelton established that a defendant was entitled to the constitutional right to counsel when the defendant received a sentence â€œthat end[s] up in the actual deprivation of a personâ€™s liberty.â€Â  Argersinger, 407 U.S. at 40, 92 S.Ct. at 2014, 32 L.Ed.2d at 540.Â  However, the Shelton decision required counsel to be appointed when an indigent defendant received a sentence that â€œmay end up in the actual deprivation of a personâ€™s liberty.â€Â  Shelton, 535 U.S. at 658, 122 S.Ct. at 1767, 152 L.Ed.2d 895 (internal quotation omitted) (emphasis added).Â  Sheltonâ€™s extension of the right to counsel was a new rule under Teague because it was not dictated by precedent existing at the time of Respondentâ€™s convictions.Â  See also Howard v. United States, 374 F.3d 1068, 1074-77 (11th Cir. 2004) (finding Shelton announced a new rule under Teague).Â  
Generally, new procedural rules should be not applied retroactively to cases on collateral review, unless the new rule falls within one of two exceptions to the general rule.Â  Teague, 489 U.S. at 305, 310, 109 S.Ct. at 1072, 103 L.Ed.2d at 352, 356.Â  The first exception is when the rule â€œplaces certain kinds of primary, private individual conduct beyond the power of the criminal law-making authority to proscribe.â€ Â Id. at 311, 109 S.Ct. at 1075, 103 L.Ed.2d at 356 (internal quotation omitted).Â  The second exception is when the rule â€œrequires the observance of those procedures thatâ€¦are implicit in the concept of ordered liberty.â€Â  Id. at 311, 109 S.Ct. at 1076, 103 L.Ed.2d at 356 (internal quotations omitted).Â  The second exception is â€œreserved for watershed rules of criminal procedureâ€ which implicate the fundamental fairness and accuracy of the proceeding.Â  Id.Â  
The first exception is not applicable to the present situation.Â  The Supreme Court has repeatedly cited Gideon as illustrative of the type of new rule which falls within the second exception in Teague.Â  See, e.g., Beard v. Banks, 542 U.S. 406, 124 S.Ct. 2504, 159 L.Ed.2d 494 (2004) (recognizing the right to counsel announced in Gideon as an example of the second Teague exception); Saffle v. Parks, 494 U.S. 484, 110 S.Ct. 1257, 108 L.Ed.2d 415 (1990) (same); Teague, 489 U.S. at 311-312, 109 S.Ct. at 1075-76, 103 L.Ed.2d at 357 (same).Â  The Supreme Court also has applied each extension of the constitutional right to counsel retroactively to collateral proceedings.Â  We conclude the new rule announced by Shelton is a watershed rule of criminal proceeding because the right to counsel undeniably implicates the fundamental fairness and accuracy of the proceeding.Â  See Howard, 374 F.3d at 1077-80 (collecting authority which supports retroactive application of every extension of right to counsel on collateral review but noting these decisions were decided prior to Teague and concluding Shelton fell within the second Teague exception because of â€œthe sheer importance of the right to counselâ€).
Because Shelton applies retroactively on collateral review, the PCR judge correctly determined S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(B) is the applicable statute of limitations.Â  Shelton was decided on May 20, 2002, and Respondent filed his PCR application on March 6, 2003.Â  Respondentâ€™s PCR application was timely filed under Â§ 17-27-45(B).
Although Respondent timely filed his PCR application and Shelton applies retroactively on collateral review, we conclude the rule announced in Shelton does not apply to Respondentâ€™s convictions.Â  Respondent only paid a fine for his conviction in 1995.Â  A fine for an uncounseled misdemeanor conviction is valid, and Respondent did not have a constitutional right to counsel for this conviction.Â  See Scott, 440 U.S. at 373-74, 99 S.Ct. at 1162, 59 L.Ed.2d at 389.Â  Accordingly, the PCR judge erred in vacating the 1995 conviction.Â  
Respondent received thirty daysâ€™ imprisonment, which was immediately suspended and conditioned on six monthsâ€™ good behavior, and was fined $940 for his 1996 conviction.Â  In South Carolina, a magistrate cannot lawfully place a person on probation.Â  A magistrate can, however, lawfully suspend a sentence and impose conditions.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-800 (Supp. 2005) (â€œNotwithstanding the limitations of Sections 17-25-100 and 24-21-410, after a conviction or plea for an offense within a magistrateâ€™s jurisdiction the magistrate at the time of sentence may suspend the imposition or execution of a sentence upon terms and conditions the magistrate considers appropriate. . . .Nothing in this section may be construed to give a magistrate the right to place a person on probation.â€).Â  Although a magistrate has the statutory authorization to suspend sentences and impose conditional sentences, we note the enforcement of substantive conditions as part of a suspended sentence may implicate a defendantâ€™s right to counsel as required by Argersinger, Scott, and Shelton.Â  In this case, the magistrateâ€™s condition of six monthsâ€™ good behavior was effectively probation, and accordingly, the probation was an illegal sentence.Â  We vacate that portion of Respondentâ€™s sentence for his 1996 conviction.[4]Â  
Therefore, Respondent lawfully received a prison sentence that was immediately suspended and a fine for his 1996 conviction.Â  If a defendant receives only an immediately suspended sentence without probation, there is absolutely no possibility the defendant will ever be incarcerated for the underlying conviction.Â  As such, the prison term for the underlying conviction will never be triggered, and the defendant has not received a sentence that â€œmay â€˜end up in the actual deprivation of a personâ€™s liberty.â€™â€Â  Shelton, 535 U.S. at 658, 122 S.Ct. at 1767, 152 L.Ed.2d at 895 (citing Argersinger, 407 U.S. at 40, 92 S.Ct. at 2014, 32 L.Ed.2d at 540).Â  Because Respondent received an immediately suspended sentence and a fine, we conclude the federal constitutional right to counsel did not apply to Respondentâ€™s conviction in 1996 and the PCR judge erroneously ruled Respondentâ€™s conviction was invalid under Shelton.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision to vacate Respondentâ€™s convictions and uphold those convictions.Â  We need not reach the remaining issue on appeal.Â  See Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that Alabama v. Shelton, 535 U.S. 654 (2002) should be applied retroactively, and I agree that decision affords Respondent no relief on his 1995 conviction.Â  I disagree, however, with the majorityâ€™s conclusion that the 1996 sentence was, at least in part, illegal and would affirm the grant of post-conviction relief (PCR) to Respondent on that conviction.
The majority holds, and I agree, that a magistrate cannot lawfully place a criminal defendant on probation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-800 (1989) (â€œNothing in this section may be construed to give a magistrate the right to place a person on probationâ€).Â  Here, the magistrate did not place Respondent on probation but instead suspended his sentence, conditioned on six months good behavior.Â  Such a suspension is explicitly authorized by Â§ 22-3-800: â€œ[T]he magistrate at the time of sentence may suspend the imposition or execution of a sentence upon terms and conditions the magistrate considers appropriateâ€¦.â€Â  A suspended sentence conditioned upon good behavior â€œis independent of the Probation and Parole Statutes and suspension of sentences therein providedâ€¦.â€Â  Richards v. Crump, 260 S.C. 133, 194 S.E.2d 575 (1973).[5]Â  I find nothing illegal about the 1996 sentence[6] and conclude that it was obtained in violation of the rule in Alabama v. Shelton.
I therefore concur in part and dissent in part.

[1]Â  Section 17-27-45(A) provides: 

  An application for relief filed pursuant to this chapter must be filed Â Â Â  within one year after the entry of a judgment of conviction or within Â  one year after the sending of the remittitur to the lower court from an Â Â Â Â Â Â  appeal or the filing of the final decision upon an appeal, whichever is Â Â Â  later.

In Peloquin v. State, 321 S.C. 468, 469 S.E.2d 606 (1996), the Court held that all defendants convicted prior to July 1, 1995, the effective date of Â§ 17-27-45, must be allowed until July 1, 1996, to file a PCR application.
[2]Â  Section 17-27-45(B) provides: 

  When a court whose decisions are binding upon the Supreme Court of this State or the Supreme Court of this State holds that the Constitution of the United States or the Constitution of South Carolina, or both, Â  impose upon state criminal proceedings a substantive standard not previously recognized or a right not in existence at the time of the state court trial, and if the standard or right is intended to be applied  retroactively, an application under this chapter may be filed not later than one year after the date on which the standard or right was determined to exist.

[3] Â The defendant in Shelton was convicted of a misdemeanor; was sentenced to thirty daysâ€™ imprisonment, which was immediately suspended; and was placed on unsupervised probation for two years.
[4]Â Â  The dissent relies on dicta in Richards v. Crump, 260 S.C. 133, 194 S.E.2d 575 (1973), to allege that a suspended sentence conditioned on good behavior is independent of probation.Â  The issue in Richards was whether a magistrate could lawfully impose consecutive sentences, and in that context, the Richards Court differentiated between consecutive and suspended sentences.
[5] I note that in Richards the parties conceded that a magistrate could not suspend sentences and thus it does not support the majorityâ€™s holding that a magistrate lacks this authority.Â  I note as well that the opinion makes no mention of Â§ 43-67.1, the predecessor to Â§ 22-3-800 then in effect.
[6] I n my view, if in fact the original sentence were unlawful, then the suspension would be a nullity and Respondent would be required to serve the original thirty day sentence.Â  As such, the 1996 conviction was obtained in violation of Argesinger v. Hamlin, 407 U.S. 25 (1972), and PCR was properly granted.

title: Franklin v. Chavis
description: In this original jurisdiction case, the Court determines that a layperson's drafting of a third party's will is the unauthorized practice of law.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      Beth Franklin and Julianne Franklin, Petitioners,
    
  

v.

  
    
      Ernest B. Chavis, Respondent.
    
  


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No. 26251
Heard October 31, 2006 - Filed January 22, 2007Â Â Â  

RELIEF GRANTED IN PART


  
    
      
        Adele J. Pope, of Law Offices of Adele J. Pope, PC, of Columbia, for petitioners.
        Thomas E. Lydon, of McAngus Goudelock & Courie, LLC, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  We accepted this case in our original jurisdiction to consider whether respondent Ernest Chavisâ€™s involvement in drafting a will and other documents for decedent Annie Belle Weiss constituted the unauthorized practice of law.
FACTS
Petitioners, who are Ms. Weissâ€™s grandnieces, commenced the underlying action[1] contesting her will on grounds of undue influence and lack of capacity.Â  Ms. Weiss was ninety-one years old and in the hospital when she signed this will on July 31, 2004.Â  Petitioners claim Michael Lehman, Ms. Weissâ€™s nephew by marriage, took advantage of her condition to influence her to make this will leaving 60% of her estate[2] to Lehman and only 10% to each of Ms. Weissâ€™s three grandnieces and their mother, Lynn Franklin.[3]Â  Respondent, a former neighbor of Ms. Weiss, drafted this will.Â  The will names respondent as personal representative of Ms. Weissâ€™s estate but he is not a beneficiary.[4]
Respondent also drafted a power of attorney that Ms. Weiss signed along with the July 31 will.Â  This document names respondent as her attorney-in-fact.Â  Respondent used this power of attorney before Ms. Weissâ€™s death to close a real estate transaction on her behalf.Â  Ms. Weiss died on September 27, 2004.
The third document in question is a Renunciation of Administration regarding the estate of Ms. Weissâ€™s daughter, Sara Crossman, who died in May 2004.Â  Ms. WeissÂ  signed this document on September 14, 2004, relinquishing her right to act as personal representative for Saraâ€™s estate and nominating respondent to act in that capacity.Â  Ms. Weiss also signed a waiver of bond form for Saraâ€™s estate enabling respondent to serve without posting bond. 
The action before us seeks a declaration that respondent engaged in the unauthorized practice of law by drafting the July 31 will, the power of attorney, and the two probate forms; a declaration that all these documents are void; an injunction; and restitution.Â  The record is replete with claims of misconduct that are relevant only to issues pending in the underlying action regarding undue influence and lack of capacity.Â  We limit the facts here to those relevant to the claim that respondent engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.
ISSUES

  1. Did respondent engage in the unauthorized practice of law?
  2.Â What relief is appropriate?

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Unauthorized practice of law
Petitioners assert respondent engaged in the practice of law by giving legal advice and preparing the above-mentioned legal documents on Ms. Weissâ€™s behalf. Â Â Respondent contends he acted as a mere scrivener.Â  
a. Drafting of July 31 will
Respondent testified that he visited Ms. Weiss socially at her home on July 20, 2004.Â  Respondent is an insurance agent by trade and previously had business dealings with Ms. Weiss.Â  During this visit, Ms. Weiss asked respondent, â€œCan you help me make a will?â€Â  Respondent agreed to help her with a simple will.Â  Ms. Weiss told him she wanted â€œsomebody objectiveâ€ and she directed respondent as to how she wanted her property divided.Â  Respondent used a â€œQuicken lawyer diskâ€ to generate a generic will on his home computer and he filled in the blanks.Â  He brought the will to Ms. Weiss on July 31 when he went to visit her in the hospital and she signed it.Â  
The preparation of legal documents constitutes the practice of law when such preparation involves the giving of advice, consultation, explanation, or recommendations on matters of law.Â  State v. Despain, 319 S.C. 317, 319, 460 S.E.2d 576, 578 (1995).Â  Even the preparation of standard forms that require no creative drafting may constitute the practice of law if one acts as more than a mere scrivener.Â  See State v. Buyers Service Co., 292 S.C. 426, 430, 357 S.E.2d 15, 17 (1987).Â  The purpose of prohibiting the unauthorized practice of law is to protect the public from incompetence in the preparation of legal documents and prevent harm resulting from inaccurate legal advice.Â  Housing Auth. of City of Charleston v. Key, 352 S.C. 26, 572 S.E.2d 284 (2002); see also In re: Baker, 85 A.2d 505, 514 (N.J. 1951) (â€œThe amateur at law is as dangerous to the community as an amateur surgeon . . . .â€).
The novel question here is whether respondentâ€™s actions in filling in the blanks in a computer-generated generic will constitute the practice of law.Â  Respondent selected the will form, filled in the information given by Ms. Weiss, and arranged the execution of the will at the hospital.Â  Although these facts are not in themselves conclusive, the omission of facts indicating Ms. Weissâ€™s involvement is significant.Â  There is no evidence Ms. Weiss reviewed the will once it was typed.Â  The will was not typed in her presence and although respondent relates the details of what Ms. Weiss told him to do, there is no indication he contemporaneously recorded her instructions and then simply transferred the information to the form.Â  
We construe the role of â€œscrivenerâ€ in this context to mean someone who does nothing more than record verbatim what the decedent says.Â  We conclude respondentâ€™s actions in drafting Ms. Weissâ€™s will exceeded those of a mere scrivener and he engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.[5]
b.Â  Drafting power of attorney
Respondent drafted a document entitled â€œGeneral Power of Attorneyâ€ for Ms. Weiss naming respondent as her attorney-in-fact allowing him on her behalf to:Â  1) open, maintain, or close financial accounts including access to safe deposit boxes; 2) sell property; 3) purchase insurance; 4) collect debts and settle claims; 5) enter contracts; 6) exercise stock rights; 7) maintain or operate business; 8) employ professional and business assistance; 9) sell, lease, mortgage and other acts regarding real estate; 10) prepare, sign, and file documents.Â  
Respondent testified at his deposition that he drafted the power of attorney around July 20 because Ms. Weiss asked him to represent her regarding the sale of some of her real estate.Â  Ms. Weiss signed the power of attorney at the hospital on July 31.Â  It was filed on August 4.Â  Respondent used the power of attorney to close the sale of Ms. Weissâ€™s real estate on August 26, about a month before her death.
There are no details regarding respondentâ€™s drafting of this document.Â  It uses legal phrasing with two pages of text and is not a simple form with filled-in blanks.Â  The document itself confers wide-ranging legal rights and would clearly require legal advice in its preparation.Â  We conclude respondent engaged in the practice of law in drafting this document.Â  
c. Probate forms
The Renunciation of Right to Administration and the Statement of Agreement to Waive Bond are probate court forms with handwritten information filled in the blanks.Â  While these forms do have legal implications, they are straight-forward and are provided to the public by the court.Â  These simple forms are clearly distinguishable from the will and power of attorney discussed above.Â  Respondent basically inserted names, addresses, and dates.Â  There is no evidence respondent gave legal advice to Ms. Weiss regarding these forms.Â  We find there is no factual support for the claim that respondent engaged in the practice of law by filling out these forms.Â  See Shortz v. Farrell, 193 A. 20 (Pa. 1937) (filling in simple forms provided by tribunal not unauthorized practice of law).
2.Â  Relief 
Petitioners ask this Court to enjoin respondent from the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Respondent states that he has no intention of assisting others in any matters related to wills or powers of attorney and therefore he does not object to an injunction.Â  
Petitioners further assert that because respondent engaged in the unauthorized practice of law in drafting Ms. Weissâ€™s will, he should be removed as personal representative.Â  We decline to order petitionerâ€™s removal based on the record before us[6] but conclude respondent should receive no fee for his services as personal representative of the Weiss estate.Â  In Linder v. Ins. Claims Consultants, Inc., 348 S.C. 477, 560 S.E.2d 612 (2002), we addressed the activities of public insurance adjusters and determined that those functions constituting the unauthorized practice of law should not be compensated.Â  Here, although respondent was not compensated for drafting the will, he is entitled to a statutory amount of compensation up to 5% of the appraised value of the estate for his services as personal representative.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-719 (Supp. 2005).Â  Respondentâ€™s entitlement to a fee as personal representative flows directly from his unauthorized practice of law in drafting a will naming himself as personal representative.Â  Accordingly, respondent shall not receive any fee as personal representative of the Weiss estate and shall disgorge any fee received thus far.
Petitioners also complain that respondent is using estate funds to defend the action below which challenges the will on the ground of undue influence.Â  This is a legitimate use of estate funds under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-720 (1987) which allows for the expenses of estate litigation to be paid by the estate.Â  The lower court may determine that respondent should be liable for these expenses depending upon its findings in the underlying action.
Petitioners contend the will drafted by respondent should be declared void.Â  We disagree.Â  The claims of undue influence and lack of capacity, which would invalidate Ms. Weissâ€™s will, are issues to be resolved in the underlying action.Â  If the July 31 will was in fact drafted pursuant to Ms. Weissâ€™s true wishes, it should not be invalidated simply because it was drafted by a nonlawyer.Â  Accord In re: Petersonâ€™s Estate, 42 N.W.2d 59 (Minn. 1950) (refusing to void a will whose validity was challenged on the ground it was drafted by a nonlawyer because testator should not be penalized by having his will declared void).[7] Â Â 
Finally, petitioners ask us to order restitution for alleged financial missteps by respondent in managing the Weiss and Crossman assets.Â  There is no private right of action in South Carolina for the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Linder v. Ins. Claims Consultants, Inc., supra.Â  Petitionersâ€™ claim for restitution is based on an alleged breach of fiduciary duty and is not appropriate relief in an action based on the unauthorized practice of law.
RELIEF GRANTED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]The action was commenced in probate court and removed by consent to circuit court.
[2]The net worth of the estate is $897,890.Â  
[3]Lynn Franklin is the daughter of Ms. Weissâ€™s sister. 
[4]Only a month earlier, on June 25th, Ms. Weiss signed a will prepared by her lawyer that names Lynn Franklin as personal representative and Lehman as the alternate.Â  This will was more favorable to petitioners.
[5]The fact that respondent received no compensation is irrelevant.Â  Housing Auth. of City of Charleston v. Key, 352 S.C. 26, 572 S.E.2d 284 (2002).Â  One court has noted that a lack of compensation in fact makes the situation worse.

  Indeed, the public may well be in greater need of protection from the unauthorized practice of law where it seems to be done without charge than where a charge is openly made for the services.Â  In the former situation, the public, through natural cupidity, are the more readily attracted to something which appears to be a â€œgiveawayâ€ project or a chance to obtain â€œsomething for nothing.â€

Grievance Committee of the Bar of Fairfield County v. Dacey, 222 A.2d 339, 351 (Conn. 1966). 
[6]Removal for cause is provided by statute under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-611 (1987), a remedy petitioners are free to request in the underlying action.Â  
[7]Regarding the power of attorney, it is no longer valid since Ms. Weiss is deceased.Â  Further, petitioners do not contest the real estate transaction accomplished pursuant to the power of attorney and there is nothing to be achieved by voiding the power of attorney now.

title: State v. New
description: In this criminal case, the Court decides that the defendant has the burden of proof regarding the affirmative defense of duress.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        John New, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lee County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26252
Heard November 15, 2006 - Filed January 22, 2007

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia; and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant John New was convicted of two counts of hostage-taking and one count of unlawfully carrying a weapon while an inmate.Â  He was sentenced consecutively to two life sentences without parole and ten years.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The charges stemmed from a hostage situation at Lee Correctional Institute which occurred on September 8, 1999.Â  Employees Janie Mathis and Jane Gardner were held in an administrative office after appellant and another inmate, Wesley Floyd, burst in on them.Â  Appellant put a knife to Ms. Mathisâ€™s throat and threatened to harm her unless the building was cleared immediately.Â  He demanded that pizza be delivered and said he wanted to speak with the warden.Â  After several hours, negotiators were finally able to convince the inmates to release their hostages unharmed.Â  Both victims testified that appellant was the decision-maker and in control of the situation, and that only appellant had a weapon.Â  
Appellant testified to the contrary that Floyd was the leader and appellant had no choice but to do as Floyd directed.Â  Floyd, a convicted murderer, had threatened appellantâ€™s life several times because appellant was indebted to Floyd for drugs.Â  On the day in question, Floyd came to appellantâ€™s cell and told him what they were going to do.Â  Appellant was afraid for his life because Floyd carried a razor blade in his mouth.[1]Â  Based on the evidence, the trial judge gave a charge on duress.Â  Â 
ISSUE

  Did the trial judge err in charging that appellant had the burden of proving his defense of duress by a preponderance of the evidence?

DISCUSSION
Over appellantâ€™s objection, the trial judge charged it was appellantâ€™s burden to prove his defense of duress by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  Appellant contends that, based on our holding in State v. Addison, 343 S.C. 290, 540 S.E.2d 449 (2001), the State should have the burden of disproving duress.Â  In Addison we held in the context of self-defense that the defendant is entitled to a charge, if requested, that the State bears the burden of disproving self-defense beyond a reasonable doubt.[2]Â  Appellant argues the same rule should apply here. Â 
State courts differ on the issue whether the State is required to disprove duress beyond a reasonable doubt;[3] however, the United States Supreme Court has recently held that due process does not require such a charge.Â  Dixon v. United States, ___ U.S. ___ , 126 S.Ct. 2437 (2006).Â  In Dixon, the Court reasoned that the prosecution need not bear the burden of disproving duress beyond a reasonable doubt because â€œthe existence of duress normally does not controvert any of the elements of the offense itself.â€Â  126 S.Ct. at 2441.Â  The Court noted that even though the defense of duress allows the defendant to avoid criminal liability, the crime was still knowingly committed.Â  Dixon resolved a conflict among the federal courts reflecting the widespread disagreement, as noted by one court, on the â€œphilosophicalâ€ question regarding whether duress negates the mens rea of the crime or whether it simply excuses the crime because it is motivated by self-preservation.Â  See United States v. Mitchell, 725 F.2d 832 (2d Cir. 1983). 
We find the rationale of Dixon persuasive.Â  Duress excuses the crime but does not negate any element of the offense.Â  See State v. Rocheville, 310 S.C. 20, 425 S.E.2d 32 (1993) (duress does not negate element of malice in murder charge); State v. Robinson, 294 S.C. 120, 363 S.E.2d 104 (1987) (duress envisions a third person compelling another to commit a crime).Â  Self-defense, on the other hand, goes to an element of the crime.Â  See State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 589 S.E.2d 1 (2003) (the â€œno faultâ€ element of self-defense opposes intent element of mutual combat); State v. Merriman, 34 S.C. 16, 12 S.E. 619, 622 (1891) (self-defense negates element of malice).Â  Accordingly, the fact that the State has the burden of disproving self-defense beyond a reasonable doubt does not compel the conclusion that the same applies to the defense of duress. 
Generally, affirmative defenses must be established by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  State v. Attardo, 263 S.C. 546, 211 S.E.2d 868 (1975).Â  We hold the trial judge properly charged the jury that appellant had the burden to prove his defense of duress by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice G. Thomas Cooper, concur.

[1]At his first trial on these charges, appellant blamed a different inmate and testified that Floyd was his friend.Â  He claimed here that he lied because Floyd was present at the first trial.
[2]The failure to give such a charge is not cured by a general charge that the State bears the burden of proving the defendantâ€™s guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298 (2002). 
[3]Compare State v. Fuller, 506 A.2d 556 (Conn. 1986); State v. B.H., 834 A.2d 1063 (N.J. 2003); State v. Culp, 900 S.W.2d 707 (Tenn. App. 1994) (State has burden of disproving duress) and State v. Jeffrey, 50 P.3d 861 (Ariz. 2003); State v. Riker, 869 P.2d 43 (Wash. 1994); Moes v. State, 284 N.W.2d 66 (Wis. 1979) (State does not have burden of disproving duress).

title: Arnal v. Fraser
description: Father raises numerous issues arising out of four different family court orders.  These four appealed orders in the current action were issued while the partiesâ€™ previous appeal was pending.  The Court affirmed in part and reversed in part.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        David Arnal, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Laura Lawton Fraser, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Judy C. Bridges, Family Court Judge
Â Wayne M. Creech, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26253
Submitted December 7, 2006 - Filed January 22, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        David Emil Arnal, of Marietta, Georgia, pro se.
        Donald B. Clark, Susan C. Rosen, and Robert N. Rosen, all of Rosen Law Firm, LLC, of Charleston, for Respondent.
        Ralph E. Tupper, of Tupper Grimsley, Dean, PA, of Beaufort, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  We certified David Arnalâ€™s (Fatherâ€™s) four appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and consolidated them for briefing purposes.Â  Father raises six issues arising out of four family court orders.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
Father and Laura Lawton Fraser (Mother) were divorced by order of the family court on October 17, 2001.Â  The amended final order awarded custody of the partiesâ€™ minor child, Samuel, to Mother, granted visitation to Father, required Father to pay child support, divided marital property, and addressed all other issues between the parties.
Father and Mother cross-appealed a total of sixteen issues arising out of the amended final order, and the Court of Appeals resolved these issues in Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 609 S.E.2d 821 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Mother petitioned this Court, and we granted certiorari to address five issues from the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision. Â This Court affirmed the Court of Appeals with modification in Arnal v. Arnal, Op. No. 26215 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed October 23, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 40 at 27) (â€œfirst appealâ€).
While the first appeal was pending, Father filed the current action (Case No. 2003-DR-07-183) in the Beaufort County family court on February 10, 2003.Â  In his complaint, Father requested modification of his child support obligation and asked for more control over health-care decisions for Samuel, who has Downâ€™s syndrome.Â  
After this action was filed in February 2003, numerous hearings have been held to address emergency motions and rule to show cause actions filed by both parties.Â  The four appealed orders stem from these hearings.
The first order suspended Fatherâ€™s overnight visitation upon Motherâ€™s motion.Â  Mother alleged Father violated previous court orders[1] by failing to videotape the administration of medications to Samuel.Â  
The second order addressed Motherâ€™s claim that Father failed to reimburse Samuelâ€™s uncovered medical expenses as required by the final divorce order.Â  The family court found Father owed Mother for uncovered medical expenses previously incurred, and the court ordered both parents to pay in advance for language tutoring and other educational expenses.Â  
In the third order, the family court found Father to be in contempt for (a) failing to provide proof of valid life insurance as required by the amended final order; (b) failing to comply with a prior order compelling discovery; and (c) failing to comply with prior orders requiring Father to videotape medicine administration.Â  The court then sentenced Father to a period of incarceration not to exceed six months for each finding of contempt but allowed Father to purge these sentences by complying with the prior orders.
One of the conditions attached to Fatherâ€™s purging of his contempt sentence was, â€œIf Father fails to provide the required video to Mother on any occasion within the following twelve (12) months after the issuance of this order, a warrant shall be issued for his arrest for failure to meet the conditions to purge the contempt.â€Â  Father initially complied with the conditions for purging his contempt sentence and avoided incarceration.
The fourth order appealed by Father was the issuance of a bench warrant for contempt.Â  Based upon affidavits by Mother and the guardian ad litem (GAL), the family court found that Father failed to comply with the provisions of the third order by not properly videotaping the medication administration within the twelve month period as required under the third order.Â  The warrant has been stayed while this appeal was pending.
ISSUES
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Should the current action (2003-DR-07-183) filed by Father, requesting child support modification and more control in Samuelâ€™s health-care decisions, be dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction?Â  If so, should the Court void and vacate all orders issued in this action?
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the family court abuse its discretion by ordering Father to pay uncovered medical expenses as a result of Motherâ€™s rule to show cause actions to enforce the final divorce order, when Father claims such expenses were not proper, reasonable, or necessary?
 III.Â Â Â Â  Did the family court err by ordering Father to pay educational and other non-medical expenses?
IV.Â Â Â Â  Did the family court abuse its discretion by terminating Fatherâ€™s overnight visitation?
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the family court err in refusing to appoint a medical GAL for Samuel?
VI.Â Â Â Â  Were the contempt sentence and requirements for purging in the third order, along with the subsequent order issuing a bench warrant for Fatherâ€™s arrest, an unconstitutional violation of Fatherâ€™s due process rights?
ANALYSIS
Issue I:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction[2]
Both parties briefed the issue of subject matter jurisdiction by analyzing the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-782 to -830 (1985) (â€œUCCJAâ€) and the Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act, 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A (2000) (â€œPKPAâ€).Â  As discussed below, the jurisdictional issues in this case are governed by Rule 205, SCACR, and by Rule 225, SCACR.Â  
Father contends that the UCCJA and the PKPA prohibit the Beaufort County family court from exercising subject matter jurisdiction over the current modification action.Â  He argues that all orders should be voided and vacated because, by the time this action was filed in February 2003, Father had moved to Georgia while Mother and Samuel lived in North Carolina.Â  We disagree.
Both the PKPA and the UCCJA govern jurisdictional disputes between courts of different states when multiple states claim jurisdiction over a custody or child visitation dispute.[3]Â  In this case, however, no other state is competing with South Carolina for jurisdiction, and the current action does not include a child custody dispute.Â  Instead, both parties rely on a Court of Appeals decision which addressed subject matter jurisdiction under the PKPA and UCCJA in a situation similar to the present case, i.e. neither parents nor child resided in South Carolina and no other state was competing for jurisdiction.Â  Widdicombe v. Tucker-Cales, 366 S.C. 75, 620 S.E.2d 333 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  However, Widdicombe only addressed custody, whereas custody has never been an issue in this case or in the first appeal.Â  
Neither the PKPA nor the UCCJA apply to the specific issues raised here.Â  The jurisdictional issues in this case are governed by Rule 205 and by Rule 225, SCACR.
Rule 205, SCACR, provides the appellate court with exclusive jurisdiction over matters on appeal.Â  The lower court may only proceed with matters not affected by the appeal.Â  Rule 225(a), SCACR, in governing matters which are stayed while on appeal, provides:

  As a general rule, the service of a notice of appeal in a civil matter acts to automatically stay matters decided in the order on appeal, and to automatically stay the relief ordered in the appealed order, judgment, or decree.Â  This automatic stay continues in effect for the duration of the appeal unless lifted by order of the trial judge, appellate court, or judge or justice thereof.Â  The lower court retains jurisdiction over matters not affected by the appeal including the authority to enforce any matters not stayed by the appeal.

(emphasis added).Â  Under Rule 205 and the last sentence of the above-quoted portion of Rule 225, the lower court may not act or issue orders that affect an issue on appeal.[4]Â  Under Rule 225, the lower court may act only to enforce matters not stayed by the appeal.
Because Fatherâ€™s payment of child support and medical expenses as required by the final divorce order were not stayed by the appeal, [5] the family court retained jurisdiction to enforce those payments.Â  However, the family court did not have jurisdiction to modify matters in the final divorce order that were on appeal.Â  Rule 205, SCACR; See also Wingate v. Wingate, 289 S.C. 574, 347 S.E.2d 878 (1986) (because alimony was an issue on appeal from the divorce decree, the Court had exclusive jurisdiction over the alimony issue, and the family court was without jurisdiction to change the amount of alimony during the pending appeal).
Accordingly, we cannot say that all orders in the present action are void for a lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Each contention made by Father must be analyzed to determine whether the family courtâ€™s decision was affected by a matter on appeal or whether Mother simply sought to enforce the amended final order.Â  
Issue II:Â Â Â Â Â  Uncovered Medical ExpensesÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the final divorce order, Mother was given complete authority to make all decisions regarding Samuelâ€™s medical and educational needs.Â  Father was required to pay his pro-rata share of 64.4% of the uncovered medical expenses.Â  Because this payment was not stayed pursuant to Rule 225(b)(6), SCACR, Father was required to pay these medical expenses, and the family court retained jurisdiction to enforce this provision during the appeal.Â  
Although the issue of apportioning medical expenses from the final divorce order was on appeal, Father did not seek to modify his obligation in the present case, and this dispute did not affect a matter on appeal.Â  Instead, Father asked the family court to determine whether the medical expenses previously submitted by Mother were subject to the provisions of the final order.Â  This issue could be addressed by the family court under Rule 205 and under Rule 225, SCACR.
Father contends that the order directing him to pay or reimburse Mother for uncovered medical expenses constituted an abuse of discretion.Â  He argues that these medical expenses were not reasonable for several reasons and claims he should not have to pay for unconventional and unnecessary treatment.Â  Father also argues that he should not have to pay medical expenses that are not submitted to insurance providers. Â We disagree.
After a hearing on the issue of medical expenses, the family court determined that the medical expenses were reasonable and proper under the final divorce order.Â  Father offered numerous reasons why the expenses did not fall under the scope of the final order, and the family court disagreed and ordered Father to pay his required share.Â  Although this Court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, we should not disregard the findings of the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999).Â  The family court did not abuse its discretion by finding Fatherâ€™s payment of the requested medical expenses to be enforceable under the final divorce order.
Issue III:Â Â Â Â  Educational and Non-medical Expenses
The amended final order specifically declined to address educational expenses.Â  Because these types of expenses were not dealt with in the final order, this matter was not affected by the appeal, and Rules 205 and 225, SCACR, would not prohibit the family court from exercising jurisdiction over this issue.
Father argues that the family court erred by requiring Father to pay his share of Samuelâ€™s educational expenses such as language and speech tutoring and early education training.Â  We disagree.
The family court did not abuse its discretion by requiring both parents to split the costs for these expenses.Â  The order required both parents to pay for language tutoring and therapist bills in advance, and the family court did not abuse its discretion in finding these expenses appropriate to Samuelâ€™s care.Â  
Issue IV:Â Â Â Â  Termination of Overnight Visitation
Father contends that the family court erred in terminating his overnight visitation for failing to meet the videotaping requirements mandated by the family court.Â  We agree, due to the jurisdictional bar of Rule 205 and Rule 225, SCACR.
The final divorce order set very specific parameters for Fatherâ€™s visitation.Â  Father appealed the portion of the final order to the Court of Appeals concerning summer and holiday visitation.Â  Thus, the family court would not have jurisdiction to modify terms of visitation because the appellate court would have exclusive jurisdiction over the matter on appeal. [6]Â  
The family court modified Fatherâ€™s visitation while the first appeal was pending.Â  By first requiring Father to videotape the administration of medicine as a condition of his visitation, and then by suspending Fatherâ€™s overnight visitation for failure to comply with the videotaping conditions, the family court violated our appellate court rules by issuing orders that were affected by a matter on appeal. Â Therefore, the order that suspended overnight visitation was void for lack of jurisdiction.
Issue V:Â Â Â Â Â  Medical GAL
Father argues the family court erred in refusing to appoint a medical GAL.Â  We disagree.
The authority to appoint a GAL solely for medical determinations comes from S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1545 (Supp. 2005).Â  That statute gives the family court absolute discretion in determining who will serve as a GAL.Â  Furthermore, the family court may appoint a GAL without consent of both parties when â€œthe court will likely not be fully informed about the facts of the case and there is a substantial dispute which necessitates a guardian ad litem.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1545(A)(1).Â  
Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1549 (Supp. 2005), the duties and responsibilities of a GAL already include authority to review medical records and the duty to conduct an independent, balanced, and impartial investigation of facts relevant to the situation of the child and the family.Â  Accordingly, the failure of the family court to appoint a GAL strictly for medical advisement did not constitute an abuse of discretion.
Issue VI:Â Â Â Â  Civil Contempt and Conditions of Purging
Father contends that the contempt sentence and purging provisions of the two orders by Judge Creech are unconstitutional violations of Fatherâ€™s rights.Â  We believe the contempt sentence was improperly based on an order for which no jurisdiction existed under Rule 225, SCACR.Â  Therefore, we reverse the finding of contempt, but we decline to address Fatherâ€™s constitutional arguments.
The finding of contempt against Father stems from his repeated failure to properly videotape the administration of Samuelâ€™s medicine.Â  As previously discussed, the initial order requiring Father to videotape the giving of medicine is void for lack of jurisdiction because that order modified the terms of Fatherâ€™s visitation, an issue which was being appealed.Â  Father cannot be held in contempt for violating an order which was void ab initio for a lack of jurisdiction.Â  See Luthi v. Luthi, 297 S.C. 306, 376 S.E.2d 782 (Ct. App. 1989) (during husbandâ€™s appeal of an equitable division award to former wife, the lower courtâ€™s order that the monetary equitable division award to former wife was a properly enrolled money judgment was void for lack of jurisdiction; as a result, the subsequent order awarding interest on the judgment was also invalid).
Because the contempt issue can be resolved without reaching Fatherâ€™s due process claims, we decline to address the constitutional issues raised by Father.Â  It is our firm policy to decline to rule on constitutional issues unless such a ruling is required.Â  In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 551 S.E.2d 235 (2001).
CONCLUSION
The four appealed orders in this case are not automatically void pursuant to the UCCJA and the PKPA.Â  Our appellate court rules control whether the issues were properly before the family court while the first appeal was pending.Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s order requiring Father to pay his share of medical expenses, and we affirm the order requiring both parents to share non-medical and educational expenses.Â  We also affirm the denial of Fatherâ€™s request for a medical GAL.Â  Finally, we reverse the suspension of Fatherâ€™s overnight visitation, and we also reverse the finding of contempt for violating an order that was void for lack of jurisdiction.
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C. J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] The previous family court orders requiring videotaping were both issued while the first appeal was pending.Â  
[2] Father raises the issue of subject matter jurisdiction for the first time on appeal.Â  Subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time, including on appeal.Â  State v. Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 604 S.E.2d 377 (2004).
[3] See 28 U.S.C. 1738A(a); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-788(a) (â€œA court of this State which is competent to decide child custody matters has jurisdiction to make a child custody determination by initial or modification decree ifâ€¦â€) (emphasis added); Clay v. Burckle, 369 S.C. 651, 633 S.E.2d 173 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œThe PKPA and UCCJA govern the subject matter jurisdiction of state courts to rule in interstate custody disputes.â€) (emphasis added); Kirylik v. Kirylik, 292 S.C. 475, 477, 357 S.E.2d 449, 450 (1987) (stating that UCCJA was enacted to prevent conflicting custody decrees between different states).
[4] A party can always seek a remand from an appellate court if the circumstances of the particular case require it.
[5] â€œFamily court orders regarding a child or requiring payment of support for a spouse or childâ€ are exceptions to the automatic stay. Rule 225(b)(6), SCACR.Â  
[6] Although conditions of visitation and the grant of additional summer and holiday visitation may not appear to be the same matter being addressed on appeal, the decisions both of the Court of Appeals and of this Court in the first appeal were impacted by the suspension of overnight visitation in deciding whether to award Father additional summer and Easter visitation. The Court of Appeals noted that Father had not been exercising overnight visitation in its opinion, while the suspension of overnight visitation came before this Court at oral argument during the first appeal.
