text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Martha Geathers, Claimant.
v.
3V, Inc., Employer,
and EBI Companies and Liberty Mutual Insurance Company,
Carriers/Defendants,
of whom EBI Companies is the Petitioner,
and Liberty Mutual Insurance Company is the Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Benjamin H. Culbertson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26254
Heard December 7, 2006 - Filed January 29, 2007Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Kirsten L. Barr, of Trask & Howell, LLC, of Mt. Pleasant, for Petitioner.
Pope D. Johnson, III, of McCutchen, Blanton, Johnson & Barnette, LLP, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  EBI Companies (EBI) argues the Court of Appeals erred in reinstating the decision of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission to apportion liability between EBI and Liberty Mutual Insurance Company (Liberty) for successive injuries to Martha Geathers (Claimant).Â  Op. No. 2004-UP-542 (S.C. Ct. App. filed October 26, 2004).Â  We agree and reverse. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the course of Claimantâ€™s employment with 3V, Inc. (Employer), she suffered successive accidental injuries to her back and leg.Â  Her first injury occurred on July 20, 1999.Â  Employerâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation insurance carrier at the time of this accident was EBI.Â  Claimant returned to work August 24, 1999.Â  She was placed on light duty for two months before she returned to full duty.Â Â  Claimant testified Dr. Wilkins released her from his care in January 2000, because she reached maximum medical improvement.
Claimantâ€™s second injury occurred on May 11, 2000.Â  Employerâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation insurance carrier at the time of this injury was Liberty.Â  Claimant returned to work on May 23, 2000, and assumed light duty.Â  Employer sent Claimant home two days later because it did not have any more light duty work for her.Â  Claimant has not worked since that time and has not applied for any other jobs.Â  
Claimant filed for workersâ€™ compensation benefits for the first injury.Â  Employer and EBI admitted Claimant sustained an injury, but denied benefits because she had reached maximum medical improvement.Â  Claimant then filed a second claim for benefits for the second injury.Â  EBI and Liberty denied benefits, maintaining Claimantâ€™s injuries were attributable to her first accident.Â  
At the hearing before the Single Commissioner, EBI argued: (1) Claimantâ€™s injuries from the first accident were no longer compensable because she had reached maximum medical improvement; (2) Dr. Wilkins released Claimant from his care in January 2000; and (3) Claimantâ€™s injuries from the second accident were not the same as her injuries from the first.Â  Liberty argued Claimant never reached maximum medical improvement and EBI should share liability with Liberty for Claimantâ€™s current injuries.Â  
Dr. Wilkins gave conflicting testimony regarding Claimantâ€™s medical condition.Â  Claimant had no appointments with Dr. Wilkins between her January 2000 visit and her May 2000 injury.Â  However, she did contact him to request prescriptions for pain medication.Â  At the time of the second accident, Claimant continued to experience back pain stemming from the first accident.Â  Although Claimant experienced the same symptoms as the first accident, she testified the symptoms were significantly worse following the second accident.Â  Â Â 
In his deposition testimony, Dr. Wilkins testified Claimant reached maximum medical improvement in January 2000 when he released her from his care with no restriction on her activity.Â  However, Dr. Wilkinsâ€™ notes did not reflect a finding of maximum medical improvement.Â  He testified he did not see Claimant again until after her second accident when she complained of the same symptoms she experienced after the first accident.Â  
Also in his deposition testimony, Dr. Wilkins was asked which accident he believed caused Claimantâ€™s current condition and he responded, â€œ[T]he problem that she had from the first and from the second and today is all the same problem.Â  The, the ideology [sic] and cause of her pain is the sameâ€¦.Â  I would consider that the second injury, per say [sic], is, was actually just an aggravation of her initial injury.â€Â  When asked if Claimantâ€™s current condition â€œflow[ed] from the first accident,â€ Dr. Wilkins responded, â€œI would say yes â€¦ if she hadnâ€™t had the original injury â€¦ I would think itâ€™d be reasonable that she probably would not have had the second injury, which is actually aggravation.â€Â  
When Dr. Wilkins testified before the Single Commissioner, he attributed Claimantâ€™s current condition to the second injury.Â  However, he consistently characterized the second accident as an aggravation of the first, and continually noted the symptoms and complaints were the same for both injuries.Â  Dr. Wilkins identified the first accident as the â€œproximate cause of the entire thing.â€
The Single Commissioner found both of Claimantâ€™s injuries compensable and found Dr. Wilkins had not released Claimant from his care or given his opinion as to maximum medical improvement based on Dr. Wilkinsâ€™ records.Â  The Single Commissioner found: 

[The second injury] was intervening, but not totally independent of the [first] accidental injury and that the [second] accidental injury aggravated, exacerbated, and worsened Claimantâ€™s condition; and the two injuries from the two accidental injuries are intertwined, indistinguishable, and inseparable beginning May 11, 2000 [the date of the second accident] and remain so as of the date of the hearing.Â  

The Single Commissioner ordered EBI to pay Claimantâ€™s benefits for the time period between the first and second accidents, and ordered EBI and Liberty to â€œshare equally in all causally related benefitsâ€ from the date of the second accident forward.Â  EBI appealed and the Full Commission affirmed. 
EBI appealed to the circuit court which reversed, finding the rule in Gordon v. E.I. Du Pont Nemours & Co., controlled, 228 S.C. 67, 76, 88 S.E.2d 844, 848 (1955) (where a non-disabling injury is aggravated with resulting disability, such disability is compensable).Â  The circuit court found no evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that Dr. Wilkins had not released Claimant as having maximum medical improvement.Â  The circuit court also found the second accident was â€œclearly distinguishableâ€ from the first accident because Claimantâ€™s need for benefits after the second accident was necessitated solely by the second accident.Â  Consequently, Liberty was found to be solely liable for Claimantâ€™s entire benefits following the second accident.Â  
The Court of Appeals reversed the decision of the circuit court and reinstated the Commissionâ€™s decision.Â  The Court of Appeals rejected EBIâ€™s argument that Gordon controlled because it found substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s finding Claimantâ€™s injuries were â€œintertwined, indistinguishable, and inseparable.â€Â  Op. No. 2004-UP-542 (S.C. Ct. App. filed October 26, 2004).Â  We granted Petitionerâ€™s petition for writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.
ISSUES

  
    
       I.   
       Does the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission have authority to apportion liability between EBI and Liberty for successive injuries to Claimant?
        
        
    
    
       II.  
      
         Did the Court of Appeals err in failing to apply the Gordon v. E.I. Du Pont Nemours & Co., 228 S.C. 67, 88 S.E.2d 844 (1955), rule to the facts of this case?Â 
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Appellate review of workersâ€™ compensation decisions is governed by the Administrative Procedures Act.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); see also Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).Â  The Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.Â  Id. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Act. No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006), a reviewing court determines whether the circuit court properly determined whether the full commissionâ€™s findings of fact are supported by substantial evidence in the record and whether the panelâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Baxter v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, but evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the agency reached.â€Â  McCraw v. Mary Black Hosp., 350 S.C. 229, 235, 565 S.E.2d 286, 289 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Authority to Apportion
EBI argues the Court of Appeals erred in finding the Commission has the authority to apportion liability for Claimantâ€™s second injury and to order EBI to pay benefits related to the second injury when EBI did not provide coverage for Employer on the date of the second injury. We agree.
A â€œsuccessive-carrier problemâ€ occurs when a worker suffers successive workplace injuries with an intervening change of employers or change of insurance carriers by the same employer.Â  9 Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 153.01[1] (2005).Â  There are two possible solutions to the successive-carrier problem.Â  
The apportionment solution has been adopted by many jurisdictions.[1]Â  The leading case establishing apportionment, Anderson v. Babcock & Wilcox Co., 175 N.E. 654, 655 (N.Y. 1931), explains the rationale for the approach:

Unjust it is that the second insurer should bear the entire liability when the second accident was related in large measure to the first.Â  No less unjust it is that the first insurer should bear the entire liability if it appears that without the second accident an earlier recovery might have been had. 

The problem with this approach is that it is complicated by statutes of limitations, out-of-state employers, and the difficulty of determining the proportion of liability attributable to each insurer.Â  9 Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law at Â§ 153.01[2].Â  South Carolina has neither statute nor case law authorizing the apportionment of workersâ€™ compensation benefits in successive injury cases.[2]Â  
The second solution to the successive-carrier problem is called the â€œlast injurious exposure ruleâ€ and it is the majority rule.[3]Â  Id. at Â§ 153.02[1].Â  This rule â€œplaces full liability upon the carrier covering the risk at the time of the most recent injury that bears a causal relation to the disability.â€Â  Id.Â  Consistent with the rule that an employer takes its employee as it finds her, the last injurious exposure rule makes the insurer at risk at the time of the second injury liable even if the second injury would have been much less severe in the absence of the prior condition and even if the prior injury significantly contributed to the final condition.Â  Id. at Â§ 153.02[2].Â  However, if the second injury is merely a recurrence of the first injury, then the insurer on the risk at the time of the original injury remains liable for the second.Â  Id. at Â§ 153.02[4].Â  The benefit of the last injurious exposure rule is it â€œprovides a reasonably equitable approach to compensation problems in the multi-employer context which is simple, easy to administer, and avoids the difficulties associated with apportionment.â€Â  82 Am.Jur.2d Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§ 200 (2003).Â  
While South Carolina has not expressly adopted the last injurious exposure rule, both statutory and case law favor adopting the rule rather than the apportionment solution.Â  First, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-430 (1985) favors placing sole liability on a single insurer.Â  It states:

Whenever a dispute arises between two or more parties as to which party is liable for the payment of workersâ€™ compensation benefits to an injured employee pursuant to the provisions of this title and there is no genuine issue of material fact as to the employeeâ€™s employment, his average weekly wage, the occurrence of an injury, the extent of the injury, and the fact that the injury arose out of and in the scope of the employment, the hearing commissioner may, in his discretion, require the disputing parties involved to pay benefits immediately to the employee and to share equally in the payment of those benefits until it is determined which party is solely liable, at which time the liable party must reimburse all other parties for the benefits they have paid to the employee â€¦.

Second, 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-409 (1976) instructs the Commission to presume the policy with the later effective date is in force â€œwhen duplicate or dual coverage exists by reason of two different insurance carriers issuing two policies to the same employer securing the same liability.â€Â  Finally, a number of cases have applied a version of the last injurious exposure rule and declined to follow the apportionment rule when dealing with occupational diseases.Â  See Glenn v. Columbia Silica Sand Co., 236 S.C. 13, 112 S.E.2d 711 (1960); Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 S.C. 378, 335 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1985); Hargrove, 360 S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604.
Since South Carolina has adopted neither the apportionment rule nor the last injurious exposure rule, this case presents a novel issue of law.Â  In the absence of authority permitting apportionment and because existing statutory authority expresses a preference for holding a single insurer liable rather than apportioning liability among multiple insurers, we adopt the last injurious exposure rule.Â  Applying this rule, we find the Court of Appeals erred in apportioning liability for Claimantâ€™s second injury.[4] Â 
II.Â  The Gordon Rule
EBI argues the Court of Appeals erred in failing to apply the principle espoused in Gordon, that aggravation of a pre-existing condition is compensable.Â  In Gordon, this Court held:

The rule is well established that where a latent or quiescent weakened, but not disabling, condition resulting from disease is by accidental injury in the course and scope of employment aggravated or accelerated or activated, with resulting disability, such disability is compensable.Â  The same principle is equally applicable where the latent, but not disabling, condition has resulted from a prior accidental injury.Â  If the disability is proximately caused by the subsequent accidental injury, compensability is referable to that, and not the earlier one. 

Id. at 76, 88 S.E.2d at 848 (internal citations omitted).Â  The Court of Appeals declined to follow Gordon because of the â€œfactual-driven nature of the Gordon decision.â€Â  On the contrary, the Gordon rule is â€œwell establishedâ€[5] and the Court of Appeals erred in limiting Gordon to its facts.Â Â Â  
The Court of Appeals distinguished Claimantâ€™s situation because her injuries were not separate and distinct but â€œintertwined, indistinguishable, and inseparable.â€Â  Gordon, according to the Court of Appeals, did not apply because it dealt with separate and distinct injuries.Â  The Court of Appeals was correct in determining the Commissionâ€™s finding of inseparability was supported by substantial evidence.Â  However, such a finding does not preclude the application of Gordon because Gordon is not limited to its particular facts.Â  Gordon applies to the instant case because: (1) Claimant suffered a non-disabling back injury during a workplace accident; (2) Claimantâ€™s disability was caused by the second accident; and (3) the second injury â€œaggravated or accelerated or activatedâ€ the pre-existing condition.Â  
Not only does the Gordon rule apply to this case, but it also reflects the essence of the last injurious exposure rule which is to hold the insurer on the risk at the time of the second injury solely liable when the second injury aggravates the first injury.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the Court of Appeals and reinstate the decision of the circuit court finding Liberty solely liable for Claimantâ€™s benefits following her second injury.Â  
 REVERSED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  See Employersâ€™ Cas. Co. v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 214 S.W.2d 774 (Ark. 1948); Argonaut Ins. Co. v. Indus. Acc. Commâ€™n, 231 Cal. App. 2d 111, 41 Cal. Rptr. 628 (Cal. Ct. App. 1964); Sauer Indus. Contracting Inc. v. Ditch, 547 So.2d 276 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1989); Johnson v. Bath Iron Works Corp., 551 A.2d 838 (Me. 1988); Arender v. Natâ€™l Sales, Inc., 193 So.2d 579 (Miss. 1967); Calabro v. Campbell Soup Co., 581 A.2d 1318 (N.J. Super. Ct. App. Div. 1990); Butts v. Ward Law France Trucking Corp., 85 A.D.2d 814 (N.Y. App. Div. 1981); Wilkerson Chevrolet, Inc. v. Mackey, 367 P.2d 162 (Okla. 1961); Merton Lumber Co. v. Indus. Commâ€™n, 50 N.W.2d 42 (Wis. 1951).
[2]Â  Cf. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-13-50 (1985) (authorizing the Commission to apportion liability between employers in cases where an employee suffers ionizing radiation injury, disability, or death attributable in part to exposure received in previous employment); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 2004) (apportionment allowed when claimant suffered one injury while simultaneously employed by two employers).Â  
[3] Â See McKeever Custom Cabinets v. Smith, 379 N.W.2d 368 (Iowa 1985); Carter v. Avondale Shipyards, Inc., 415 So.2d 174 (La. 1981); Aseltine v. Leto Constr. Co., 204 N.W.2d 262 (Mich. Ct. App. 1972); Jensen v. Kronickâ€™s Floor Covering Serv., 245 N.W.2d 230 (Minn. 1976); Collett Elec. v. Dubovik, 911 P.2d 1192 (Nev. 1996); Rose City Van & Storage v. McGuire, 811 P.2d 1387 (Or. Ct. App. 1991); Novak v. C.J. Grossenberg & Son, 232 N.W.2d 463 (S.D. 1975); Bennett v. Howard Johnsons Motor Lodge, 714 S.W.2d 273 (Tenn. 1986); Davine Brown Chevrolet Co. v. Indus. Commâ€™n, 511 P.2d 743 (Utah 1973).Â  
[4]Â  The Single Commissioner erred in finding apportionment to be a factual finding.Â  Because of the legal analysis required, it is a legal conclusion.
[5] Â The rule is based on five published opinions and American Jurisprudence: Cole v. State Highway Depâ€™t, 190 S.C. 142, 2 S.E.2d 490 (1939); Green v. City of Bennettsville, 197 S.C. 313, 15 S.E.2d 334 (1941); Ferguson v. State Highway Depâ€™t, 197 S.C. 520, 15 S.E.2d 775 (1941); Cromer v. Newberry Cotton Mills, 201 S.C. 349, 23 S.E.2d 19 (1942); Ducker v. Duncan Mills, 218 S.C. 465, 63 S.E.2d 314 (1951); 58 Am.Jur. Workmenâ€™s Compensation Â§ 278 (1948).Â  It has also been cited three times by this Court: Kearse v. S.C. Wildlife Res. Depâ€™t, 236 S.C. 540, 115 S.E.2d 183 (1960); Arnold v. Benjamin Booth Co., 257 S.C. 337, 185 S.E.2d 830 (1971); Wright v. Graniteville Co., 266 S.C. 88, 221 S.E.2d 777 (1976).Â

description: We affirm the decision of the circuit court reversing the denial of Appellantâ€™s charter school application.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Lee County School District Board of Trustees, Appellant,
v.
MLD Charter School Academy Planning Committee,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lee County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26255 Â Â Â Â 
Heard September 20, 2006 - Filed January 29, 2007

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Charles J. Boykin and Karla McLawhorn Hawkins, of Boykin, Davis, Hawkins & Caldwell, L.L.C., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Cathy Hoefer McCabe, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
Kenneth L. Childs, William F. Halligan, John M. Reagle, Allison Aiken Hanna, all of Childs & Halligan, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae Laurens County School Districts 55 & 56.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Respondent MLD Charter School Academy Planning Committee (the Academy) appealed the decision of Appellant Lee County School District Board of Trustees (Lee Board) denying its application for a charter school.Â  The State Board of Education (State Board) reversed the decision of the Lee Board and the circuit court affirmed.Â  We affirm as modified.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Lee Board is a duly-elected local school board of trustees which manages and controls the Lee County School District.Â  The Lee Boardâ€™s duties include evaluating applications to form charter schools pursuant to the South Carolina Charter Schools Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 59-40-10 to 210 (2004).Â  The Academy is a charter school which has been operating in Lee County since the fall of 2005.Â  The Academy submitted an application to the Charter School Advisory Committee (Advisory Committee), which was established by the State Board to review and determine the compliance of a charter school application with the requirements of the Charter Schools Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-70(A).Â  
After the Academy met with the Lee Board and the Advisory Committee on several occasions, the Advisory Committee voted to certify the application.Â  The Advisory Committee forwarded the Lee Board a certified application and notified the Lee Board of its decision in a letter.Â  At a public hearing, the Lee Board voted to deny the Academyâ€™s application.Â  In its Notice of Denial, the Lee Board stated that the application was not compliant with the requirements of the Charter Schools Act in at least seven areas.Â  The Lee Board also expressed its belief that approving the application would adversely impact other students in Lee County.Â  
The Academy appealed the decision of the Lee Board to the State Board arguing, among other things, that the Lee Boardâ€™s only concerns were financial in nature and that its bases for denial of the application were erroneous.Â  The State Board reversed the decision of the Lee Board and, in effect, granted a charter to the Academy.Â  The State Board found the order of the Lee Board lacked specificity because it did not base its findings of fact or conclusions of law on substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Although the State Board determined it could reverse on this basis alone, it also found the Academy met the statutory requirements in ten areas found deficient by the Lee Board.Â  
The Lee Board appealed the order of the State Board.Â  The Circuit Court affirmed.Â  We certified the appeal from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  
ISSUES

  
    
       I.   
       Did the circuit court err in finding no conflict existed between S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-70(A)(6) (2004), which requires all applications to be completed by the State Boardâ€™s published deadline, and 24 S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 43-601(I)(C) (Supp. 2005), which permits the Advisory Committee to request and consider additional application materials after the deadline has passed?
    
    
      
       
    
    
       II. 
       Did the circuit court err in applying a more stringent notification requirement upon the Lee Board than set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-70(C) (2004)?
    
    
      
       
    
    
       III.    
       Did the circuit court err in affirming the State Boardâ€™s reversal of the Lee Board based solely on the contents of the Notice of Denial?
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The circuit court reviews the order of the State Board under the Administrative Procedures Act (APA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005), which provides for reversal only if its findings are:

a)    in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;
b)    in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;
c)    made upon unlawful procedure;
d)    affected by other error of law;
e)    clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record; or
f)      arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.

This Court reviews the order of the circuit court to determine whether it properly applied the APA standard of review.Â  Beaufort County Bd. of Educ. v. Lighthouse Charter
Sch., 335 S.C. 230, 516 S.E.2d 655 (1999).Â  Although under the APA, the Court may not substitute its judgment for that of a state agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, it may reverse or modify decisions which are clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Welch Moving and Storage Co., Inc. v. Public Serv. Commâ€™n of South Carolina, 301 S.C. 259, 391 S.E.2d 556 (1990).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Conflict between Statute and Regulation
The Lee Board argues the circuit court erred in finding no
conflict existed between S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-70(A)(6), which requires all applications to be completed by the State Boardâ€™s published deadline, and 24 S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 43-601(I)(C), which permits the Advisory Committee to request and consider additional application materials after the deadline has passed.Â  The Lee Board failed to raise this argument to the State Board and, therefore, failed to preserve this issue for appellate review.Â  This Court has a limited scope of review and cannot consider issues that were not raised to and ruled on by the administrative agency.Â  Kiawah Resort Assoc. v. South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 502, 458 S.E.2d 542 (1995).Â 
However, in the interest of judicial economy, we conclude there is no conflict between S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-70(A)(6) and 24 S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 43-601(I)(C).Â  Section 59-40-70(A)(6) instructs the Advisory Committee: â€œIf the [charter school] application is in noncompliance, it must be returned to the applicant with deficiencies noted.â€Â  We do not interpret this provision as mandatory. Â Regulation 43-601(I)(C) allows the Advisory Committee to â€œrequest clarification or additional information from the applicantâ€ and gives the Committee â€œthe authority to incorporate this additional information into the application.â€Â  The regulation is a proper and reasonable exercise of authority and, therefore, does not conflict with the statute.Â  
II.Â  The Notification Requirement
The Lee Board argues the State Board erroneously applied a more stringent notification requirement upon the Lee Board than that provided in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-70(C), which requires local school boards to provide a written explanation of the reasons for denial with correlating statutory standards.Â  We disagree.
The Lee Board failed to meet the statutory requirements set forth in Section 59-40-70(C) which states:

A local school board of trustees shall only deny an application if the application does not meet the requirements specified in Section 59-40-50 or 59-40-60, fails to meet the spirit and intent of this chapter, or adversely affects, as defined in regulation, the other students in the district.Â  It shall provide, within 10 days, a written explanation of the reasons for denial, citing specific standards related to provisions of Section[s] 59-40-50 or 59-40-60 that the application violates.

Instead of providing a â€œwritten explanation for the reasons for denial, citing specific standards,â€ the Lee Board spoke only in generalized terms in its Notice of Denial.Â  Section 59-40-70(C) clearly sets forth the requirements the Lee Board must follow, and the Lee Board failed to meet these requirements in its Notice of Denial.Â  The circuit court was, therefore, correct in affirming the State Boardâ€™s decision to reverse the Lee Board.
III.Â  The Notice of Denial
The Lee Board argues the State Board erroneously based its decision solely on the contents of the Lee Boardâ€™s Notice of Denial instead of the entire record, which purportedly contained evidence that supported the decision of the Lee Board to deny the charter school application.Â  We disagree.Â  
The State Board properly based its decision on the Lee Boardâ€™s Notice of Denial.Â  Porter v. South Carolina Public Service Commission, 333 S.C. 12, 507 S.E.2d 328 (1998),[1] established the requirement for administrative agencies when presenting their findings:

An administrative body must make findings which are sufficiently detailed to enable this Court to determine whether the findings are supported by the evidence and whether the law has been applied properly to those findings. Where material facts are in dispute, the administrative body must make specific, express findings of fact. An administrative agency is not required to present its findings of fact and reasoning in any particular format, although the better practice is to present them in an organized and regimented manner â€¦. We occasionally have upheld [administrative] orders which were conclusory in nature.Â  We did so in years past because no statute explicitly required an administrative agency to make specific findings of fact or state its reasoning as a predicate for judicial review - although we have long believed that is the better practice â€¦. [S]tatutes and our precedent require an administrative agency to make specific findings of fact and explain its rationale in sufficient detail to afford judicial review.Â  

Porter, 333 S.C. at 21-22 n. 3, 507 S.E.2d at 332-333 n.3 (citations omitted). 
Porter also explained that courts will not sua sponte search the record for substantial evidence supporting a decision when an administrative agencyâ€™s order inadequately sets forth the agencyâ€™s findings of fact and reasoning.Â  Id.Â  
The Lee Boardâ€™s decision is embodied in its Notice of Denial.Â  Neither the State Board, the circuit court, nor this Court is obligated to search the entire record for information that should have been contained in the Notice of Denial.Â  Because the Lee Board failed to support its findings in the Notice of Denial with sufficient detail, the circuit court did not err in affirming the State Boardâ€™s reversal of the Lee Board.Â  
CONCLUSION
The Lee Board failed to provide the requisite specificity in its Notice of Denial and failed to comply with the requirements of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-40-70(C).Â  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision to affirm the State Boardâ€™s reversal of the Lee Board.Â  Our disposition of these issues makes it unnecessary to address the Lee Boardâ€™s remaining issues.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (an appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issues is dispositive).Â  
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent and, as explained below, would vacate the circuit courtâ€™s order and remand the matter to that court for reconsideration.
The majority holds that â€œ[t]he circuit court reviews the order of the State Board under the Administrative Procedures Act (APA)â€¦.â€Â  I disagree,[2] and would hold that the charter school appeal process for cases such as this which commenced before July 1, 2000, lies entirely outside the APA.Â  In my opinion, the confusion that has resulted from the misapplication of the APA by the circuit court renders the order before us incapable of intelligent review such that a remand is required.
In 1996, the General Assembly enacted the â€œSouth Carolina Charter Schools Act of 1996 (the Act),â€ [3] codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 59-40-10 et seq.Â  Pursuant to the Act, if the local board denies an application â€œthe charter applicant may appeal the denial to the State Board of Education pursuant to Section 59-40-90.â€Â  This section establishes the procedure for these appeals, and allows the State Board to affirm or reverse the local boardâ€™s action.Â  Â§ 59-40-90(C).Â  Under the Act, the State Board acts as an appellate body in reviewing the local boardâ€™s decision.Â  The State Boardâ€™s scope of review and standard of review in this appellate process in found in 24 S.C. Regs. 43-600(1)(D) and (E).[4]
Under the version of the Act in effect at the time this case arose, the â€œfinal decision of the state board may be appealed by any party to the circuit court for the county in which the proposed charter school is or was to have located [sic].â€Â  Â§ 59-40-90(D).Â  This right to appeal to the circuit court exists pursuant to the Act, not the APA.Â  As an appeal outside the ambit of the APA, the circuit courtâ€™s jurisdiction is founded on S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-10 (1985) and its scope of review is governed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 18-7-170 through -190 (1985).Â  In my view, the conclusion that this appeal lies outside the APA is confirmed by 2006 Act No. 274.Â  This act, effective July 1, 2006, amends Â§ 59-40-90 to provide that charter school appeals from the state board are now made to the Administrative Law Court.
The circuit court reviewed this appeal under the APA rather than under the Title 18 standards.Â  As a result, this Court cannot perform its appellate function with any degree of certainty.Â  I would therefore vacate the circuit court order and remand for reconsideration under the Title 18 standard.Â  See Karl Sitte Plumbing Co., Inc. v. Darby Dev. Co. of Columbia, Inc., 295 S.C. 70, 367 S.E.2d 162 (Ct. App. 1988) (circuit court order applying wrong standard of review reversed and remanded for
redetermination).

[1]  Although Porter addresses the Public Service Commission, we find it applicable to all administrative agencies, including local school boards.Â  
[2]  I also disagree with Part III of the majorityâ€™s opinion which analyzes the sufficiency of the Lee Boardâ€™s Notice of Determination under an APA standard.Â  A local school board is not an agency within the meaning of the APA, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-310(2) (2005): in my opinion, the expansion of this definition to include local institutions intrudes on the Legislatureâ€™s prerogative, and is unduly burdensome to those entities.
[3]  1996 Act No. 447, Â§ 2, as amended by 2002 Act No. 341, Â§ 1.
[4]  Among other things, this regulation requires the State Board when acting in its appellate capacity under the Act to apply standards very similar to those used by a circuit court when reviewing an APA appeal.

title: Cannon v. SCDPPS
description: This case involves the issue of whether the Court of Appeals erred by finding petitioner was required to submit a DNA sample for inclusion in the State's DNA database as a condition of his parole.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
John Hall Cannon, Petitioner,
v.
South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services,
Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
  TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26256
Heard November 2, 2006 - Filed January 29, 2007Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Richard A. Harpootlian and Graham L. Newman, of Richard A. Harpootlian, P.A., of Columbia, for petitioner.
Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Assistant Chief Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, and Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr., of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE MOORE: Â Petitioner instituted a declaratory judgment action to determine whether the South Carolina Deoxyribonucleic Acid (DNA) Identification Record Database Act[1] (the Act) required him, as a condition of his parole, to submit a DNA sample to the stateâ€™s database.Â  The trial court held the Act applied to petitioner and required him to submit a sample.Â  The court further held the Act did not violate the ex post facto clause.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Cannon v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole and Pardon Servs., 361 S.C. 425, 604 S.E.2d 709 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We reverse.
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err by finding petitioner was required to submit a DNA sample for inclusion in the Stateâ€™s DNA database as a condition of his parole?

DISCUSSION
Petitioner was convicted of murder in 1972, and was sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  His conviction and sentence were affirmed on direct appeal.[2]Â  He subsequently pled guilty to two additional counts of murder and unlawfully carrying a pistol and received concurrent life sentences.Â  All three counts arose from the same event.
After serving over eleven years on the concurrent life sentences, petitioner was paroled on October 12, 1983.Â  He was to remain on parole for the rest of his life.Â  The conditions of his supervised release did not call for submitting any type of sample, but he was required to â€œcarry out all instructions [his parole agent] gives.â€
In 1995, South Carolina enacted the Act, requiring a person â€œcurrently paroled and remaining under supervision of the Stateâ€ to provide a DNA sample as a condition of parole.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-620(C) (Supp. 1995).Â  The Act was subsequently amended in July 2000, to require a sample from someone â€œconvicted or adjudicated delinquent before July 1, 2000, who is serving a probated sentence or is paroled on or after July 1, 2000.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-620(E)(1) (Supp. 2000).[3]
In 2001, respondent informed petitioner he was required to provide a DNA sample as a condition of his parole and his failure to do so would constitute a parole violation.Â  Petitioner instituted this action, asking whether the Act requires him to submit a DNA sample.Â  Petitionerâ€™s motion for a temporary restraining order was granted and respondent was enjoined from requiring petitioner to provide a sample of his DNA pending the outcome of this action.
The statute at issue, Â§ 23-3-620(E)(1) (Supp. 2000), states:

(E)  At such time as possible and before release from confinement or release from the agencyâ€™s jurisdiction, a suitable sample from which DNA may be obtained for inclusion in the State DNA Database must be provided as a condition of probation or parole by:
  
(1) A person convicted . . . before July 1, 2000, who is serving a probated sentence or is paroled on or after July 1, 2000, for: [one or more enumerated crimes];[4] and
(2) any criminal offender ordered by the court who was convicted . . . before July 1, 2000, and who is serving a probated sentence or is paroled on or after July 1, 2000.
  

Petitioner argued to the trial court that the word â€œparoledâ€ refers to an individual who is â€œreleased to paroleâ€ on or after July 1, 2000, and that because he was released to parole prior to that day, the Act does not apply to him. The court found that such a construction of the word â€œparoledâ€ would limit the statuteâ€™s operation and would be destructive of its intent.Â  The court found it was the intent of the legislature to include all individuals currently paroled in the database.Â  Therefore, the court held that petitioner must provide a sample as a condition of his parole. Â The Court of Appeals affirmed.
 We find the Act is inapplicable to petitioner because the Legislatureâ€™s act of amending the statute in 2000 shows that a departure from the original law was intended. Â See Kerr v. State, 345 S.C. 183, 547 S.E.2d 494 (2001) (adoption of amendment which materially changes statuteâ€™s terminology raises presumption that departure from original law was intended).Â  It is presumed the Legislature, in adopting an amendment to a statute, intended to make some change in the existing law. Â Vernon v. Harleysville Mut. Cas. Co., 244 S.C. 152, 135 S.E.2d 841 (1964). Â See also Denene, Inc. v. City of Charleston, 352 S.C. 208, 574 S.E.2d 196 (2002) (it must be presumed the Legislature did not intend a futile act, but rather intended its statutes to accomplish something); Stuckey v. State Budget and Control Bd., 339 S.C. 397, 529 S.E.2d 706 (2000) (subsequent statutory amendment may be interpreted as clarifying original legislative intent).Â  Accordingly, as petitioner contends, we find the plain wording of the statute indicates the word â€œparoledâ€ refers to an individual who is â€œreleased to paroleâ€ on or after July 1, 2000.Â  See Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 420 S.E.2d 843 (1992) (words of a statute must be given their
plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation); Burns v. State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co., 297 S.C. 520, 377 S.E.2d 569 (1989) (cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate Legislatureâ€™s intent).
Our disposition of this issue makes it unnecessary to address petitionerâ€™s ex post facto argument.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issue when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â  Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
REVERSED.
WALLER, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Edward W. Miller, concur.

[1]S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 23-3-600 through 700 (Supp. 2000).
[2]State v. Cannon, 260 S.C. 537, 197 S.E.2d 678, cert. denied, 414 U.S. 1067 (1973).
[3]Since petitioner filed this action, the Act was amended again in 2004.Â  The only amendment to the phrase in question is a change in date, and the statute states a sample is a condition of parole for â€œa person convicted or adjudicated delinquent before July 1, 2004, who is serving a probated sentence or is paroled on or after July 1, 2004.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-3-620(E)(1) (Supp. 2005).
[4]A person convicted of a violent crime is subject to the Act.Â  A violent crime is defined in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (Supp. 2005) and includes the crime of murder.Â  Â
